direction.raw_text: plays, 154 sonnets, and several epic poems that are collectively known as the ultimate expressions of humanity in the English language. And yet... And yet... (beat) Not a single manuscript of any kind has ever been found written in Shakespeare's own hand. In four hundred years, not one document-- be it poem, play, diary or even a simple letter. (beat) He was born the son of a glove-maker, and at some unknown time, armed with but an elementary school education, he went to London where, the story goes, he became an actor and eventually a playwright. OFF STAGE A stagehand takes a wooden hammer and beats against a flat metal pate, creating the SOUNDS of THUNDER. Another stagehand starts to lift shutters in front of a stage light back and forth to create LIGHTNING STRIKES. ON STAGE "Prologue" opens his umbrella.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He died at the age of 56, and was survived by his wife and two daughters who were, like Shakespeare's own father, irrefutably illiterate. 2 pg. 3 OFF STAGE In the rafters a stagehand opens valves.   It starts to RAIN.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: His will famously left his second best bed to his widow. But it made no mention of a single book or manuscript. The actor who will play "Ben JONSON" (mid 30's) appears in the wings, bearded, ready to go on stage, holding a prop leather manuscript. Behind him a group of Elizabethan "soldiers" strap on their swords. ON STAGE "Prologue" continues, as do TITLES.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Is it possible Shakespeare owned no books at his death because... he could not read? That he wrote no letters because he, like his father before him and his children after him, could not write? (lets that sink in, then) Our Shakespeare is a cypher, a ghost; his biography made not by history... but by conjecture. His story not written with facts, but with... imagination. The rain has intensified. "Prologue" turns and the camera starts to leave him and the TITLES END....
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (more energetic) So! Let me offer you a different story. A darker story... Of quills and swords. Of power and betrayal. Of a stage conquered, and a throne lost! A FLASH OF LIGHTNING, and for a moment only sheets of RAIN are visible. No stage, no "Prologue". Then, trough the rain, we see a form of a man... Ben Jonson... running. Then we make out the shapes of houses... a street. We're not on a stage anymore. We are: 3 pg. 4 6    EXT. BANKSIDE LONDON - 1604 NIGHT                             6 Jonson-- carrying the manuscript-- runs up the street toward a large circular theater. He frantically opens the wooden door to the theater-- 7    INT. THE ROSE THEATER - NIGHT                                 7 --and he quickly bolts it behind him, turns, and desperately looks for a place to hide. He runs towards the stage as-- 8    EXT. THE ROSE THEATER - CONTINUOUS                            8 About a dozen uniformed guards reach the door. They are led by Sir Richard POLE (40), Captain of the Guard.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Break it down! And several of the guards charge the door with their pikes, HITTING it hard.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Again! 9    INT. THE ROSE THEATER - CONTINUOUS                            9 Jonson hurries backstage, and disappears from our view just as-- 10   EXT/INT. THE ROSE THEATER - CONTINUOUS                    10 --the guards SMASH the door open.    Pole is the first in.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Jonson!   Jonson!!    Show yourself! The soldiers immediately spread out into different parts of the theater. Jonson's gone. Because-- JONSON has moved under the stage silently scurrying like a rat trying to find a place to hide among the stacks of props and costumes (swords, masks, flags and banners, shields, barrels, canons, etc.) But Jonson freezes when he sees-- 4 pg. 5 THROUGH THE CRACKS OF THE STAGE'S FLOORBOARDS --the soldiers jump onto the stage and spread out, Pole amongst them.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Out with you! Jonson! We'll smoke you out like a rat if we have to! (beat) Jonson?! Jonson!! Nothing.    A beat, then--
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (to a soldier) Torch it. The soldier hesitates.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Torch it!   All of you! The soldiers obey, lighting fire to the walls, the galleries, the columns as-- JONSON GASPS in horror. Desperate-- he spies an open metal box nearby filled with un-used fireworks. He tosses the fireworks out of the box-- and then places the bound manuscripts in their place, then closes the box. Then-- he grabs a nearby rapier as-- FLAMES --begin to take hold everywhere: the columns at the front of the stage... the trompe-l'oeil walls... the seating galleries... the columns... A TRAP DOOR opens center-stage, and Jonson JUMPS out, the rapier in his right hand, ready for a fight. But-- three soldiers jump onto the stage, pikes ready. Jonson-- no fool- turns and runs for the other end of the stage-- but then runs smack into four other soldiers! Ballocks! Jonson turns this way and that-- nowhere to run-- grins wryly, drops his sword. Raises his hands in surrender. 5 pg. 6 11   EXT. THE ROSE THEATER - NIGHT                            11 Jonson, his hands tied behind him, is pushed through the door, Pole following. A small crowd of actors, whores, etc., watch the theater burn. The guards have to push their way through them. INSERT The fire reaches the fireworks below the theater's stage, and-- BACK TO SCENE -- the SOUND of fireworks EXPLODING makes Jonson turn and see: THE THEATER Timbers CRASH and fireworks EXPLODE over the theater. 12   EXT. THE THAMES RIVER - DAWN                             12 A longboat carrying Jonson, Pole and the guards makes its way towards the Tower Of London. 13   INT. TOWER OF LONDON - AN INTERROGATION ROOM - DAWN      13 Jonson is thrown into a chair, a guard on either side of him. It's dark-- the only light coming from a few torches in the walls, and a large fire pit at the far side of the room. An INTERROGATOR (30's) faces him.   Dressed all in black, he is wispy thin.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You are Benjamin Jonson, playwright? Son of William Jonson, glass-blower, son of James Jonson brick-layer? Jonson nods.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: And have you ever been arrested before, Mr. Jonson?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'm a writer, aren't I?   Of course I've bloody well been-- 6 pg. 7 And a guard BACKHANDS Jonson on the face full force-- hard enough to send Jonson and the chair to the ground. His nose starts to bleed. As the Guards pull him up, the Interrogator looks across the room-- there is someone else there, a FIGURE, watching, but cloaked in the darkness. Jonson notices the figure as well.      We hear a voice from the darkness.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Ask him about the plays.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Plays? (to the Figure) Which would you prefer, my lord? A pastoral? An historical? An historical-pastoral, or an hysterical historical pastoral-- And SMACK!    He's hit by the guards again.   He SPITS out a tooth.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: We are not interested in your plays, Jonson. We are interested in the plays given to you by Edward de Vere, Earl of Oxford. Jonson stares at him a beat, and then looks into the darkness.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'm sorry my lord, but I am not sure I know whereof you speak. I have had the honor of meeting his lordship-- And SMACK-- FLASH CUT TO: FACES laughing. Not in this room, somewhere else. Somewhere outside. Before we really understand what we are seeing we are: BACK IN THE CELL Jonson blinks, trying to stay conscious.      His mouth is ripped, bleeding. So is his nose. 7 pg. 8 The skin has broken on his forehead.     The Interrogator leans into the bloody Jonson.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Where are the plays? Before Jonson even has a chance to answer-- SMACK!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: : MORE FACES Laughing.    We are: 14   INT. THE ROSE THEATER - DAY                                  14 And it is nine years earlier. The faces come from an audience watching a play. They find the performance hysterical. 15   EXT. ROSE THEATER/BANKSIDE LONDON - CONTINUOUS               15 The Rose towers above the nearby buildings "Bankside" (the part of London that houses the theaters, whorehouses, etc.). The Rose towers above the nearby buildings "Bankside" (the part of London that houses the theaters, whorehouses, etc.).
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Well? TWO MEN walk towards the theater. Edward de Vere (47), the Earl of OXFORD, an intensely handsome man. His clothes have seen better days. His companion is Henry Wriothesley, Earl of SOUTHAMPTON (22). Blonde, attractive, a bit of a pretty boy-- and extremely enthusiastic.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Wonderful, isn't it?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Well, it's certainly... big. 8 pg. 9 SOUTHAMPTON I promise you, Edward, you've seen nothing like it before! Nothing!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Bricklayers and whores watching Aristophones?   You're quite right, Henry, not only have I never witnessed it, I'm not sure I care to.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (teasing) You're an elitist, you know that, Edward? Oxford pauses at the entrance.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: There won't be puppets, will there? Southampton grins and gives a few coins to an USHER, who escorts the two of them (the retainers stay outside) inside.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: My lords... INT. THE ENTRY OF THE ROSE THEATER - CONTINUOUS The usher takes them up a flight of stairs.    Oxford observes everything as they walk.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The stage-craft is quite spectacular. Far more elaborate than anything I've seen at court. I've witnessed be- headings that god as my witness look as real as at the Tower, cannons fired in battle... They come to the second floor, where a SELLING-MAID has a box of food and drink in front of her bosom-- much like a match-stick girl.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Ale?   Mutton, mi' lord? Southampton waves her off as they follow the usher up another flight of stairs. 9 pg. 10 SOUTHAMPTON ...and last week, they had some sort of a device to hoist cherubs into the air and fly over the entire audience!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: An apo mekhanes theos. Deus ex machina. Machine of the Gods. And as they ascend up more stairs, Oxford catches glimpses of the stage and performance through the rafters and over the heads of the attending audience.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Whenever the Greeks wrote their heroes into a situation from which they couldn't write their way out-- Oxford is becoming intrigued by the theater, almost despite himself.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: --Out came the apo mekhanes theos... As when Hippolytus is saved by Artemis, or Medea flown to Athens... Always good for an apo mekhanes theos was Euripides Oxford continues up, two steps behind Southampton. They come to the third floor and enter the box seating area reserved for nobles, giving Oxford his first real look at the theater itself. Oxford looks around and sees- FROM OXFORD'S POV Audience members LAUGHING-- others DRINKING-- maids SELLING food-- the actors ACTING... It's alive.   Magical. BACK TO OXFORD Oxford takes it all in, almost stunned by it. ON-STAGE The actor William SHAKESPEARE (30) plays a commoner. He is handsome, sexy, charismatic; and holds a tankard of ale, and SWIGS from it constantly. Another actor SPENCER (30) plays "FASTIDIOUS"; a pompous, over-dressed, caricature of a nobleman.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: pg. 11 He wears an enormous feather on his hat. Also on stage is an actor called John HEMINGE (late 40's), who plays "Sogliardo"
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: And whither were you riding now, signior?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Who, I? What a silly jest's that! Whither should I ride but to the court?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: pardon me, sir, twenty places more; your hot-house, your pig-house, or your whore-house! The audience ROARS in laughter as Shakespeare looks below at a buxom young lady among the "groundlings". He smiles seductively. She smiles back. BACKSTAGE Jonson (now 25 and clean-shaven) is watching the performance from behind a curtain, silently speaking the lines with the actors. IN THE RAISED SEATING A group of playwrights and poets watch the play with an air of judgement. They are: Christopher "Kit" MARLOWE (32), young, brilliant, a bit foppish (he likes the boys), Thomas NASHE (late 30's)-- a heavy-set, a hard drinking satirist-- and Thomas DEKKER (29), considered a bit of a hack by his colleagues. They are called the "Mermaid's Wits" because they frequent a pub named The Mermaid's Tavern.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (takes a swig of ale) His second play, and almost a full house. (burps) He's got a wit, does Jonson.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: That might be so, but like a grain of wheat hid in a bushel of chaff: you shall seek all day ere you find it, and when you have it, it's not worth the search!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: pg. 12 The others smile as a WOMAN passes.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Ale!   Ale!!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Marlowe-- spot me a few pence, will you? Henslowe still owes me for "Shoemaker's Holiday".
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (retrieving coins) That would be because no one saw "Shoemaker's Holiday".
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Ale here! Marlowe gives the woman a few pennies as--
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Kit... Isn't that one of your unrequited loves in the box over there? Marlowe glances across the theater and spots Southampton siting next to Oxford.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (frowns) But with whom? Tell me not he prefers the company of such old grey men as that! Nashe squints.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I think-- yes, by the beard, that's the Earl of Oxford. Old Tom Hooker used to play for him. Had his own acting troupe for private Court performances and the like.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I wonder if he needs any material?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Certainly not any of yours.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No, no-- that was years ago. Had a falling out with the Queen, I heard. He's more of a recluse than a patron these days.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: pg. 13 ON STAGE Shakespeare points to "Fastidious".
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Who, he, the noble there? Why, he's a gull, a fool, no salt in him i' the earth; man, he looks like a fresh salmon kept in a tub! Shakespeare struts around as though he owned the place. The more he talks, the more the audience ROARS in laughter.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He sleeps with a musk-cat every night, and walks all day hang'd in perfumed chains for penance.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Oi!   So that's what I been smelling! More groundlings laugh.     Interestingly-- NOBLEMEN in the box seats do not. ON STAGE Shakespeare continues his rant, speaking directly to the groundlings.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He has his skin tann'd in civet, to make his complexion strong, and the sweetness of his youth lasting in the sense of his sweet lady. And, sadly, the poor man's brain is lighter than his feather... As the audience HOWLS in laughter, we see: A NOBLEMAN with a feathered hat gets up in fury, and exits the theater, his lady with him. The Audience LAUGHS at him as he goes. ON STAGE Shakespeare smiles triumphantly.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: pg. 14 SHAKESPEARE (CONT'D) He is a good and empty puff, but he loves you well, signior. I wish you well with him. OXFORD Watches the nobleman with the big feathered hat pass by. BACKSTAGE Later in the play... Shakespeare returns backstage and takes a deep swig from his tankard. He's actually drunk, though his performance didn't show it at all. He spots Jonson, and grabs him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Jonson! Wonderful dialogue! Wonderful. I hope your next--
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Will!   Will Shakespeare! Shakespeare turns to see a furious Philip HENSLOWE (50'S) heading his way.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: That's not ale in that goblet is it? Shakespeare hides the goblet behind his back.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Ale? Me? Drink during a performance? I am a professional sir! (burps) A complete and-- He is interrupted by SCREAMS.    Not from actors on stage, but by the audience. IN THE THEATER Complete panic erupts as dozens of The Queen's Guard STORM into the theater. Everyone tries to get out as quickly as possible, including the other actors, Henry CONDELL (20's), Thomas POPE (30's), William SLY (13). SIR RICHARD POLE, THE CAPTAIN OF THE GUARD --jumps on stage.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: pg. 15 POLE This play has been declared seditious and illegal by Lord William Cecil! The audience begins to BOO at the mention of Cecil.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: All are herewith ordered to disperse immediately!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Why don't you disperse William Cecil's arse!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Arrest that man! IN OXFORD'S BOX SOUTHAMPTON Damn it all.    Well! Off to Essex's then? He gets up. Oxford does not, seemingly interested in the real drama below as everyone hurries from the theater.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Edward? Oxford turns to him, distracted, and nods. ON STAGE Jonson pushes his way on stage.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (to Pole) Seditious? Seditious?! It's a comedy for god's sake! There's nothing seditious about--
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Oi, is that right, is it?    And you know this because?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Because I wrote the bloody thing!      And- -
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Arrest him as well! Jonson is grabbed by guards.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: pg. 16 17   INT. A JAIL CELL - DAY                                        17 Jonson is THROWN into the cell, the door SLAMMED behind him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: A pox on you! (beat) And your carbuncled father! Jonson looks around-- the cell is filled with a dozen or so other prisoners.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: People taxed to the point of starvation, Spain running the New World, open revolt in Ireland, Catholic plots everywhere you turn...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: : 18   INT. TENNIS COURT AT ESSEX HOUSE - DAY                        18 Robert, Earl of ESSEX (28), is playing tennis against Southampton. He's handsome, red-headed, and, we will learn, very ambitious.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: ...and how do the Cecils spend their time and energy? Shutting a theater! A theater, for god's sake? It's madness! No wonder the mob hates them so! The court is inside, and slightly different from today's game: the back walls are playable, somewhat like racquet-ball. Oxford sits on a bench, watching.   Essex SLAMS a shot, but it goes--
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Out! Essex looks furious, but holds his tongue.   Southampton prepares to serve.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Henry, how many people were at that play?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: pg. 17 Southampton pauses before serving.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Hmm? I'm not sure, two thousand, maybe more. Southampton SERVES.   Essex returns, and another heated rally begins.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: And how many performances are there of a play like that?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Five or six I suppose. He HITS the ball again, and this time Essex misses it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: By the--!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: So! Ten thousand souls. All listening to the writings of one man-- the ideas of one man. That's power, Robert. And if there is one thing the Cecils understand, it's power.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: And when did words ever win a kingdom? I think I'll keep my sword, thank you very much. Southampton SERVES as Oxford smiles at Essex's naivete. 19   INT. CHANGING ROOMS/ESSEX HOUSE - DAY                      19 Southampton and Essex are dressing out of their tennis clothes and into their normal clothes, assisted by two valets.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Leave us. (they exit) Henry... Some of my men have... intercepted... some of William Cecil's recent correspondence with King James of Scotland...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: pg. 18 Southampton pauses in clothing himself.   This is serious.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Cecil's all but promising him the throne...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: To James?   Elizabeth would never agree to-
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Elizabeth is old. Ill. Not of her old mind. Sometimes she doesn't even recognize me. And yet, still she refuses to name an heir.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: But a Scotsman? On the Tudor throne?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You are not in the Privy Council. Elizabeth does everything the Cecils wish of her. Everything! BEHIND THEM Oxford enters. They don't notice, though. He instantly realizes he shouldn't say anything. He listens as: WIDER
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Think, Henry, if James owes Cecil his throne, Cecil will have more influence in the next reign than he does in this one. And after William Cecil, his hunch-backed son will take his place... (careful) That is why we must do everything in our power to ensure that the right man succeeds her. (beat) A man deserving of the Tudor crown. Southampton stiffens at that last phrase.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I ask you for the support of you and your men, Henry.... if it comes to a fight.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: pg. 19 Southampton looks at Essex hard.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You know you need not ask. I stand with you, as I always have. Essex smiles at him warmly. They both HEAR something shuffle behind them. They turn, and see: WHERE OXFORD WAS STANDING Nothing.   He is gone. BACK TO SOUTHAMPTON AND ESSEX They exchange a slightly worried look.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: : 20   EXT. ESSEX HOUSE - DAY                                         20 Moments later, Oxford and Southampton are exiting the elaborate building that serves as Essex's London residence.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Essex played rather poorly, didn't he? Southampton just nods, distracted.   Oxford reaches out to him, and touches his shoulder.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Henry... The Cecils brook no rivals. Southampton pauses, confused for an instant, then--
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You heard? Oxford nods.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Always concerned for me, aren't you Edward? They keep walking towards Southampton's men.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: And what would you have me do?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: pg. 20 OXFORD I would have you deny him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The son of the Queen?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: That is rumor only, Henry-- They stop. Southampton makes sure that his men are out of earshot.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Rumor? My god, all you have to do is look at Essex to see the Queen's reflection. Everyone thinks he's her son, everyone! And I for one would rather bow to a Tudor, bastard though he may be, than a Scotsman!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I desire nothing more than to see the next king be the rightful king. But what Essex contemplates will surely lead to Civil War. (beat) No. If this is to be done, it must be done carefully, skillfully.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: As I heard it, Elizabeth exiled you from her presence for the last twenty years because of your "skill" at Court politics. And then he feels instantly ashamed of having said that.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I only have your interests in mind, Henry. For as you so rightly point out, my interests are already lost.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I know. Forgive me. You know how I feel about you. You have been a great friend to me ever since my father died. I promise you that I will do nothing rash without consulting you first. Oxford nods, still worried, and Southampton heads for his horse.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: pg. 21 OXFORD Henry! Will you do me one thing more? Deliver a gift for me? A rather... elaborate gift? 21   EXT. CECIL HOUSE - SUNSET                                  21 The stone house is nothing like a stereotypical Tudor house; it's enormous, and very ornate and intricate in design. It faces the river, and has an elaborate docking area which is now filled with all sorts of longboats letting the noblemen off for a week-end get away. 22   INT. CECIL HOUSE - GREAT HALL - DUSK                       22 Most of England's nobility is assembled in small groups, talking. It's a dour, quiet affair. Some music, no life. Quite Puritan. Southampton is there, but Essex and Oxford are nowhere to be seen. A HUNCH-BACKED MAN --makes his way through the room, causing conversations to cease as he walks by. Even the most senior of the nobles bow their heads slightly in greeting him. This is Sir ROBERT CECIL (mid 30's). He pauses near Southampton.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Sir Robert.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: My lord of Southampton. (looking around) Have you seen Essex?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I believe he is still in the viewing chamber with her majesty...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Alone?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: pg. 22 SOUTHAMPTON (smiles) With your father in London dealing with all the troubles in Ireland, who else should the Queen turn to but Essex? Robert Cecil looks annoyed, but holds his tongue as the SOUND of pikes HITTING the floor silences the hall. A FOOTMAN clears his throat and--
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: By the grace of god, her majesty, Elizabeth, Queen of England, Wales and Ireland! DOUBLE DOORS open, and Elizabeth (in her 60's) enters. She is wearing a large sparkling pearl-encrusted dress with a wide collar. She walks slowly and carefully, and has a slight tremor in her head and hands. She seems un-certain; like she's not sure she recognizes all the faces around her (Alzheimer's?). And she compensates for it by being all the more regal, all the more un-human. Essex is on her arm, dressed in a splendid jewel- encrusted doublet. Robert Cecil FROWNS at the sight of Essex on her arm. Essex ignores Cecil's glare, notices Southampton--
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (to Elizabeth) Ah-- Majesty, I've been told my lord of Southampton has a gift for you.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (eyes sparkle) A gift?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yes, your grace, though not from me. Southampton CLAPS his hands and a door across the room OPENS. A DWARF enters, followed by dancing faires, actors swirling sparklers, and musicians playing music.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: pg. 23 Elizabeth's rheumy eyes widen in complete delight, a smile of total jubilation crosses her face. Robert Cecil, on the other hand, looks horrified.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Are you this gift, my precious little man?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No, no, my most majestic majesty. I am a free man. My gift is a play, majesty.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: A play? The dwarf bows his assent.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (to the Dwarf) Plays are the work of the devil, born from a cesspool of plague, whoredom, thievery, fornication, and heresy. You may tell your master that her majesty--
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (interrupting) --Will gladly accept your gift. Robert Cecil turns to Essex, shocked.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (to Elizabeth) Of course that is if you so desire, majesty. (to Robert Cecil) The choice is her majesty's to make, not yours. Is that not so Sir Robert? Robert frowns as Elizabeth looks around, unsure of the political tides around her. Then--
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (to the dwarf) Comedy? Or tragedy?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Comedy, majesty.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (delighted) A comedy! (MORE)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: pg. 24 ELIZABETH (CONT'D) (beat) By whom?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: By... Anonymous, your majesty...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Anonymous...? (then) Oh, but I do so admire his verse... Elizabeth lets go of Essex, and offers her hand to the Dwarf, who smiles brightly.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Lead us to this gift. And the Dwarf leads Elizabeth towards the door. Essex follows, and Southampton locks into step next to him. They exchange a knowing look as-- Robert Cecil steps in line far after the Queen, not happy with this turn of events as we hear--
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Bless thee, Bottom! Bless thee!      Thou art translated!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: : 23   EXT. THE GROUNDS AT CECIL HOUSE - NIGHT                          23 Sheer magic. Candles everywhere: in stakes, in the ground, in the trees. They light a make-shift "stage" surrounded by huge oak trees on three sides.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I see their knavery: this is to make an ass of me; to fright me, if they could. But I will not stir from this place, do what they can. Chairs have been brought out and put in rows in the grass. Elizabeth is watching center front row (of course). She loves it, SQUEALING in delight like a young woman. Essex is next to her.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: pg. 25 ON STAGE Several actors are mid-scene in "A Midsummer Night's Dream" (Act 3, Scene 1), their make-up quite elaborate and fantastical: "Bottom", who is costumed as a man-- except that he has a DONKEY'S HEAD, "Quince", a commoner, "Puck", played by the dwarf who is now dressed like a cupid, and "Titania", Queen of the fairies, who is presently asleep in a bed of fur. Puck hides behind a tree watching.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I will walk up and down here, and I will sing, that they shall hear I am not afraid. BACKSTAGE Oxford watches from behind a curtain, carefully observing the Queen's reaction. Somehow we feel that seeing her again after so many years stirs up some deep emotion in him. ON STAGE "BOTTOM" (CONT'D) (sings) The ousel cock so black of hue, With orange-tawny bill, The throstle with his note so true, The wren with little quill-- Titania awakens in her nest-like bed of fur.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What angel wakes me from my flow'ry bed? ELIZABETH strongly reacts to Titania awakening.   It stirs some memory in her. A pleasant memory. OXFORD watches, delighted by her reaction. FROM HIS POV We see Elizabeth watching. But it is an Elizabeth only 26 years old (referred to as YOUNG ELIZABETH in this script). We HEAR the sound of other dialogue, but from the same play. We are:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: pg. 26 24   INT. HEDINGHAM CASTLE - GREAT HALL - NIGHT                    24 Thirty-eight years earlier. And YOUNG ELIZABETH watches an earlier, slightly less sophisticated staging of "A Midsummer Night's Dream" (the costumes and sets are a bit more thrown together). All the actors are children from 7-12 years old or so. FROM BACKSTAGE A boy watches in the exact same position as we just saw Oxford. This is BOY OXFORD-- now only 10 years old. But he is made up and wears a winged costume for the character of "Puck".
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: ...and the owner of it blest ever shall in safety rest. Trip away; make no stay; meet me all by break of day. And the characters of "Oberon" and "Titania" exit.     Boy Oxford hurries-- ON STAGE "PUCK" If we shadows have offended, think but this, and all is mended, that you have but slumber'd here while these visions did appear... Next to Young Elizabeth, JOHN DE VERE, Oxford's father, also watches, his face beaming with pride.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: ...And this weak and idle theme, No more yielding but a dream, gentles, do not reprehend; if you pardon, we will mend. A STERN LOOKING MAN is watching a few seats   away from Young Elizabeth.   He is WILLIAM CECIL (40's,   Robert's father). He is a Puritan, dressed all in   black (with a white lace collar), and has a long   beard. He is frowning, loathing the play.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: pg. 27 ON STAGE "PUCK" (CONT'D) So, good night unto you all. Give me your hands, if we be friends, and Robin shall restore amends. The play now over, Young Elizabeth applauds with delight, as do the small group of courtiers all around her.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Lovely.    Lovely!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: : 25   INT. HEDINGHAM CASTLE - KITCHEN - LATER                        25 A make-shift "back-stage" where all the young "actors" are removing their costumes and make-up, including Boy Oxford, who sits in front of a make-shift, leaning mirror. Much excited talking and commotion, until Boy Oxford notices everyone has gone silent. He turns-- his winged costume still on-- just as--
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Ah!    There he is. Young Elizabeth and her senior Court, including William Cecil and John De Vere, have entered. Boy Oxford bows deeply.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Your father tells me you wrote this evening's play yourself. Boy Oxford glances at his father-- should he answer directly? His father NODS.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I did indeed, your majesty.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You sport with me. (smiling) Compose something.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Now?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: pg. 28 YOUNG ELIZABETH Yes.   Now.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: On what subject, your grace? She thinks.   Then--
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (smiles) Truth...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (thinks, then--) For... Truth... is Truth... Though... never so old... and time cannot make that false, which once was true. She smiles, claps.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (to John de Vere) My lord of Oxford. It seems you have added a poet to your family's long line of warriors.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Madam, I am as accomplished with the sword and the musket as I am with verse.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (amused) Are you indeed?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (nods seriously) It is my only desire to one day be your majesty's most trusted servant in matters both of war and state, if you will but have me.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (charmed) Why, Lord Cecil, it seems we may very well have found your replacement.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: We hope not too soon, majesty, we hope not too soon.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: pg. 29 YOUNG ELIZABETH (teasing) And how liked you our young lord's play, William? William Cecil stiffens in discomfort.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Our Lord Cecil is our most religious of subjects, and no doubt thinks your little masque will deliver your soul straight into the arms of Lucifer himself. Don't you, William? The Boy Oxford looks at William Cecil, perplexed by such a thing.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: That is God's decision, your majesty. Not mine. William Cecil looks directly at John de Vere resulting in an uncomfortable silence. Elizabeth notices.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Well, if plays are indeed such a sin, I pray I do not find my salvation until very late in life. Boy Oxford smiles.   He might very well be in love.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: : 26   INT. A JAIL CELL - DAY                                        26 Thirty-eight years later. The door SWEEPS open and a snoring, sleeping Jonson is awakened by--
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Jonson!    Ben Jonson! The other prisoners make way as the guard approaches Jonson. The guard tosses a wax-sealed piece of parchment onto Jonson's lap.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You've been released. Jonson looks at it, confused.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: pg. 30 GUARD (CONT'D) Got powerful friends, now, don't you? 26A   EXT. A BOAT - RIVER THAMES - DAY                                26A Jonson is in a nobleman's longboat (for the first time in his life). Across from him sits FRANCESCO-- Italian, 60's-- wearing a doublet with the Oxford coat of arms on its chest. The City of London is far in the distance. Jonson looks around uncomfortably at the luxurious boat for a moment before--
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: And who are you? Francesco just stares back.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: And where are we going? Francesco is silent. WIDER The boat approaches a large stone house, Oxford Stone.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: : A RED ROSE as it is cut from its bush by ink-stained hands.       We are: 27    EXT. OXFORD STONE - GARDEN - DAY                                 27 Oxford smells the rose, inhaling its essence. Then he turns and sees Francesco escorting Ben Jonson towards him. Before they reach him he glances at his wife ANNE De Vere (40's) who sits in the distance knitting with one of their daughter's, BRIDGET (17). Jonson is quite uncomfortable to be at such a grand place. Jonson CLEARS his throat.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: My lord...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: pg. 31 OXFORD The Tudor rose. The most beautiful of flowers, don't you think?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It looks to me to have quite a number of thorns, my lord.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: So it does.   So it does.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I am told, my lord, that I owe my freedom to you.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: That is true. And it was quite hard to come by. One does not cross my father-in-law lightly. Jonson doesn't know who he is talking about.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Lord William Cecil. I have the questionable distinction of being married to his only daughter. Oxford looks over to his wife who watches them suspiciously. He begins to walk away forcing Jonson and Francesco to follow.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It did, however, serve as helpful when I wrote to your jailers to release you in my father-in-law's name. Jonson suddenly looks worried and turns and looks back to Anne.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (in a panicked whisper) My lord-- I'm sorry, does that mean my release is not officially sanctioned?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Don't be an idiot Jonson, of course it wasn't. (beat) But you are free, are you not? They have come to an entrance to a GARDEN MAZE and Anne watches them as they disappear into the maze.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: pg. 32 28   EXT. MAZE - DAY                                           28 Oxford turns to Jonson.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I enjoyed your little comedy last week, Jonson. You have potential, great potential.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Thank you, my lord.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: But it's politics did seem to have quite an effect on the Tower. My father-in-law's men felt it quite seditious.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Politics? My play had nothing to do with politics! It was just a simple comedy--
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: That showed your betters as fools who go through life barely managing to get food from plate to mouth, were it not for the cleverness of their servants. (beat) All art is political, Jonson. Otherwise it would just be decoration. And all artists have something to say, otherwise... they'd make shoes. And you're not a cobbler, are you, Jonson? As they enter the center of the maze, Oxford turns to his servant.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Francesco. Francesco steps forward and hands Jonson a leather bound manuscript. Jonson looks at it confused and opens it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: A play, my lord?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: One you shall stage Bankside.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Stage?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: pg. 33 OXFORD Under your name.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: My name, my lord?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I can't very well use my name, can I? I'm the seventeenth Earl of Oxford. The Lord Great Chamberlain of England, Viscount Bolebec, Lord Escales, Sandford and Badlesmere, etc, etc. No. I have a... reputation to protect. In my world, one does not write plays, Jonson. People like you do. Jonson tries not to be offended.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yes. My lord. You wrote an entire play, my lord. I know how difficult--
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Not a play, Jonson, I've written many. No doubt, many more than you yourself. A good number performed at Court years ago, others never seen by a living soul.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: And you want... me to apply my name to this play?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No. I mean you to put your name to all of them.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: All of them?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Well don't look like I just gutted your pet dog, Jonson. I mean to make you the most popular-- and therefore the most monetarily successful-- playwright in all of London. Jonson pales.   This is a disaster for him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I wish you god speed and good morrow. Jonson looks down at the manuscript, reads a few lines.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: pg. 34 JONSON My lord-- I really-- He looks up, but Oxford is gone, having left the maze without so much as a good-bye.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: My lord? But before he can follow, Francesco tosses a leather pouch of coins at his feet.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: That is for your trouble, Signor Jonson. And your silence. If I hear you break that silence, then... not so good for Signor Jonson. And Francesco follows after his master as Jonson picks up the pouch, examining its contents. And then Jonson realizes he doesn't know how to get out of the maze. He chases after them.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Hello?   My lord?! I-- And he's lost. He looks this way and that, then picks a path (the wrong one). 29   EXT. CECIL HOUSE - DAY                                      29 Robert Cecil is standing at the opulent river   entrance to Cecil House, waiting for an enormous barge   docking. William Cecil (now 75) is at the front of the   barge, waiting to disembark. He constantly holds an    ornately carved white cane.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: So! I am gone for three days, and you somehow manage to let her spend all of them solely in the company of the Earl of Essex... Robert Cecil looks at him sharply.   How did he know.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Don't think because I was in London, I didn't know exactly what went on here in my absence.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: pg. 35 ROBERT CECIL He is an Earl, father. I cannot deny him--
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Of course not! You don't deny him anything. You find excuses. She is unwell, she is reading, she is seeing the Ambassador from Russia. For God's sake, use your imagination, Robert. Whatever will you do when I am gone? (beat) We will have to deal with Essex soon. His ambitions are becoming a nuisance. 30   INT. CECIL HOUSE - HALLWAY - DAY                           30 William Cecil enters an impressive hallway and turns to his son.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Now tell me about the play. Robert Cecil looks surprised for an instant that he knows about that as well.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It-- it was an anonymous gift. Essex insisted it be performed, just to spite me in front of Court...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Of course he did. (concerned) But what was it about?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: About? Some nonsense about fairies and cherubs.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: ...And dancing asses? Robert looks surprised at his father who has stopped suddenly.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Edward... (to Robert Cecil) Have you any idea what you have-- No, how could you...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: pg. 36 And he starts back up the stairs.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Father...    It was just a play...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: And do you know how long it took me to banish them from her presence? She adores them! Adores them! And Edward knows it. (beat) Mark my words, Robert, he has done this for a purpose.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Purpose?    What purpose?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What purpose indeed? (to Robert) But through your carelessness I must now deal not only with Essex, but Edward as well. For whether in shadow or in person, Edward has returned to Court! And with that he slams the door shut. Robert Cecil walks over to a nearby window. Visibly upset he starts to stare out of the window and remembers...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: : 31   OMIT                                                          31 THROUGH A THIRD STORY WINDOW We see servants carrying big trunks. There are at least 120 men on horses. They all wear the Oxford's crest.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Robert. 32   INT. CECIL HOUSE - HALLWAY - DAY                              32 And it is thirty years earlier. BOY ROBERT CECIL (now 9) is staring out of the window. His back must have been deformed either in utero or at birth, because even now he is hunchbacked.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: pg. 37 WILLIAM CECIL(O.S.) (more commanding) Robert! Come here. Finally Boy Robert Cecil turns and sees Young Oxford (now 17) entering the hallway with William Cecil and his wife and daughter, Young ANNE (15). In front of them, lined up, are several men whom we will learn are TUTORS. Boy Robert Cecil doesn't move.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (to Young Oxford) I am sorry, my lord. But my son Robert prefers the company... of himself... Boy Robert Cecil watches as his father turns to his mother and sister.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: May I present my wife, Lady Cecil, and my daughter, Anne. Young Anne curtsies.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I am sorry for your loss, my lord. The realm lost a great lord with your father's death. We hope you will be happy in our house--
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Are you going to live here forever? Everybody turns and sees the odd hunchback child has finally come over.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (smiles) No.    Only until I reach my maturity.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Why?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Because the Queen has bade it so. (to Young Oxford) My lord, when we first met, you said you wished to become a great man of State. Both the Queen and I hope to make that so. (MORE)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: pg. 38 WILLIAM CECIL (CONT'D) To that end, I have the honor of introducing you to your tutors. (indicates one of them) Seven to eight you shall be tutored in French by Mister Crane--
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Monsieur. Ca me fait plaisir de vous connaitre. Master Crane bows his head.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Nine to ten is Greek with Mister Simmons.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (in Greek) Dalon, an d'ego, hoti mathamata ge esti ha trafo psychas.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Is that Homer?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (sharp) No.   Plato. Boy Robert frowns at the correction.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (slight frown, then) And you know your uncle, Mister Golding, who has petitioned me to allow you to assist him in his translations of ancient Latin texts into English.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (in Latin) Continetne, ut spero, Ovidii Metamorphose? Mihi honori erit, patrue Mister Golding bows his head in appreciation.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Then cosmography with Doctor Richards. Two to three is geography and history, and four to five fencing. William Cecil seems to have finished.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: pg. 39 YOUNG OXFORD (to William Cecil) And composition? Poetry?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: This is a Puritan home, your grace. We believe such activities to be the worship of false idols, and therefore a sin before the eyes of God.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: A sin? But surely there must be room for beauty and art in life, my lord.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Not in this household. 33   INT. CECIL HOUSE - GREAT HALL - DAY                         33 Young Oxford is fencing with a tutor. He's quite good. In fact, he's better than the tutor, who is twice his age. Boy Robert Cecil casually watches as he plays chess against himself. Young Oxford, with a fierce, beautifully executed attack, disarms his tutor. The tutor's sword FLIES into the air, and hits-- THE CHESS BOARD making the pieces scatter. WIDER Boy Robert Cecil looks up, his face furious, to see Young Oxford coming over to him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You were losing anyway.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I was also winning. Young Oxford picks up the sword, throws it to his tutor, who catches it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You know I am going to one day succeed my father at the Queen's side. Not you.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: pg. 40 Young Oxford motions to go, then picks up the black king, and tosses it to Boy Robert Cecil, who can't catch it because of his deformity. It CLANGS on the floor.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Really? 34   INT. CECIL HOUSE - HALLWAY - DAY                           34 Moments later, the Young Oxford heads down the hall alone, heading for his rooms, his sword still in his hand.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: : POEMS neatly written on parchment.   We are: 35   INT. CECIL HOUSE - YOUNG OXFORD'S ROOM - DAY               35 And a SERVANT is looking at the poems, then quickly stuffing them into a bag. But then he HEARS footsteps coming. Panicked, he looks for someplace to hide-- a tapestry half covers a door-- he runs to it-- the door is locked! So he hides behind the tapestry just as the door opens, and Young Oxford enters. After a few steps, Young Oxford senses something amiss. Looks at his-- WRITING DESK where the parchments are scattered. YOUNG OXFORD goes to his desk, picks up one of the pieces of parchment. It has poetry on it. His poetry. He goes through some other pages. And realizes other pages are missing. He becomes infuriated. He sees-- UNDER THE TAPESTRY Two feet. 40 pg. 41 WIDER Young Oxford CHARGES the tapestry, sword in hand.     He THRUSTS the sword THROUGH the tapestry. The man screams in agony as he falls. He doesn't just die, but screams and screams and screams. Young Oxford steps back-- half in horror... half in triumph. The SOUND of APPLAUSE takes us to: 36   INT. THE ROSE THEATER - BACKSTAGE - DAY                      36 Thirty-three years later. Shakespeare is on stage, taking a bow. The audience is APPLAUDING and SCREAMING their approval of a performance that has just ended. He steps backwards-- BACKSTAGE --where Jonson stands holding the manuscript Oxford gave him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Is it any good?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: How in blazes should I know?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You haven't even read it? And Shakespeare is drawn back-- ON STAGE --where he bows again, then steps-- BACKSTAGE --so Jonson can answer him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I read a line or two-- I promised Henslowe I'd finish "Eastward Ho" by Saturday.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: And you say he's a nobleman? Jonson doesn't answer.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: pg. 42 SHAKESPEARE (CONT'D) Powerful?   Rich?? Jonson still doesn't answer, which is answer enough.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Ohhhh, you have to do it then, don't you? And Shakespeare goes back on stage. 37   EXT. BANKSIDE LONDON - DAY                                  37 Jonson and Shakespeare are walking along Bankside, still mid-conversation. They pass all sorts of vendors selling fish, fresh water, food, etc...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I tell you Will-- I came to London to become a great poet, to, to, be the conscience of our times, the soul of our age! To change the world, not to become someone else's--
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Change the world? With rhyme?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yes, why not? Why can't a man change the world with words? Shakespeare laughs at him.
direction.name: direction

result.heading: 5 THROUGH THE CRACKS OF THE STAGE'S FLOORBOARDS
THE ENTRY OF THE ROSE THEATER
RICHARD POLE, THE CAPTAIN OF THE GUARD

direction.raw_text: can make you the most popular and the richest playwright in all of London." (takes a swig) Ballocks! I can do that myself, thank you very much. 38   INT. THE MERMAID'S TAVERN - NIGHT                           38 Shakespeare is perusing the manuscript.   Some of the actors from the Rose are in the BG.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You know, it's actually not half bad...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: pg. 43 Jonson takes a swig of ale, then--
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Not half--?! You're an actor, what in God's name do you know about writing?! He's an amateur, Will, a complete and utter amateur. Last week gardening, this week playwrighting, next week hawking. (takes another swig) No. I won't do it. It would be an affront against the Muses...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Well we musn't offend the muses, whatever we do. (thinks, then) How much money did you say he gave you?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What, you think my name can be bought, if the number's great enough, do you? Shakespeare smiles enigmatically.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No, not at all... I think we should keep your good name quite intact, thank you very much. Jonson frowns, confused as we--
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: : A RED WIG as it is placed on the head of Elizabeth.   We are: 39   INT. WHITEHALL PALACE - OLD ELIZABETH'S BEDROOM - DAY           39 Elizabeth is behind an elaborately painted screen. Several ladies-in-waiting attend her, helping her get ready for the day. It's an intricate process. Make- up, multiple articles of clothing, jewelry...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: King Philip of Spain sees the current Catholic revolt in Ireland as a weakness of ours. A weakness to be exploited....
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: pg. 44 Elizabeth's wig is being glued into place.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Ireland? THE OTHER SIDE OF THE SCREEN (THEN INTERCUT EACH SIDE OF SCREEN AS NEEDED) William Cecil hasn't realized that his son Robert has sneaked in the room behind him to listen in.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: There are rumors of his sending financial aid, and even troops. We must act quickly. (beat) We must replace the Lord Lieutenant of Ireland, and send additional troops immediately, majesty.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Replace?   With whom? William Cecil hesitates slightly, then--
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I would recommend the Earl of Essex, your majesty.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Essex?  To Ireland? (frowns) For how long?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: As long as the present crisis warrants, majesty.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Impossible. He cannot be spared. We feel his counsel is of greater import with each passing day. Not what William Cecil wanted to hear.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I only recommend we send your most able subjects where they are most needed, majesty. (beat, a last-ditch effort) Philip of Spain dreams still of taking your kingdom from you. (MORE)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: pg. 45 WILLIAM CECIL (CONT'D) Of burning you at the stake as a heretic. Give him a foot-hold in Ireland, and--
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: But Essex?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Essex's martial abilities are, in my opinion, the only antidote to the plague of Philip. (clears his throat) Though, Essex would not, unfortunately, be able to remain in the Privy Council if he is in Ireland...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: And who would you advise to replace him? Three ladies-in-waiting approach with three different gown. Elizabeth studies them as:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Sir Robert Cecil.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Your son?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He is my own advisor first, my son second, majesty. His counsel has been invaluable to me, and no doubt will be to you as well. Elizabeth points to one of the dresses, and waves the handmaidens away.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yes, yes, yes. We will send Essex to Ireland and place Robert on my Privy Council. But William's flash of victory is dampened by--
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I saw a play this last weekend, William. It made me think of... days long past. Of memories... long past. Long past. I should like to see more of them... Has Edward been happy, William? With your daughter?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: pg. 46 William Cecil doesn't answer. Instead he thinks, remembers, as we hear his younger voice...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Murdered!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: : 40   INT. CECIL HOUSE - GREAT HALL - DAY                           40 Thirty years earlier. William Cecil is standing in front of an enormous fireplace, pacing in a pique of anger.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: By your own hand!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He was stealing my poems.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He was doing my bidding!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yours?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Of course. As soon as Robert informed me that you were disobeying my express--
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Robert?   Robert told-- William Cecil SLAMS his fists on a table.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Enough! Thou shalt not worship false idols in my household! Your everlasting soul hangs in the balance. Not poems. Your soul!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: My poems are my soul! William Cecil turns away in frustration as much as disgust.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You have placed me in a grave position, Edward. (MORE)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: pg. 47 WILLIAM CECIL (CONT'D) I cannot have my reputation soiled by this regrettable lack of control on your part... No. I will not have it. We can claim self-defense, he drew sword first. (beat) But... I wish something in return. Young Oxford looks worried.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: My daughter is young, impressionable. She has feelings for you, Edward. It is to be expected, living in such close quarters...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Sir. For the last three years you have managed to seize much of my inheritance--
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Hold your tongue, Edward, before you make a claim you cannot retract! I have been legally reimbursed for your education and living expenses.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: And now you suggest you be "reimbursed" the rest of my once considerable estates through your daughter's bed? William Cecil studies Young Oxford's face.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No. This is how I suggest you keep your noble head from the executioner's block. YOUNG OXFORD stares at him.   The SOUND of CHURCH BELLS RINGING takes us to: 41   INT. WESTMINSTER ABBEY - DAY                                41 And Young Oxford and Anne are being married by a bishop.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: pg. 48 BISHOP ...and in the fear of god, duly considering the causes for which matrimony was ordained. One was the procreation of children... WILLIAM CECIL appears triumphant.   He looks beaming over to...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: ...to be brought up in the fear and nurture of the Lord and praise of God. Secondly, it was ordained for a remedy against sin. YOUNG ELIZABETH Who presides over the whole affair. The first time we see a dress on her which makes her truly regal.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Thirdly, for the mutual society, help and comfort, that the one ought to have of the other, both in prosperity and adversity, into the which holiest state these two persons present come now to be joined. AT THE ALTAR Young Anne looks at her young husband, lovingly. Young Oxford is a bit overwhelmed and unsure of it all. And then we HEAR a trumpet BLARING, which takes us to: 42   INT. THE ROSE THEATER - DAY                                 42 Thirty-two years later. Vendors hawk food and drink as they walk through the audience. IN OXFORD'S BOX Oxford sits, Francesco behind him, exhilarated by the scene below him. IN THE GALLERIES Marlowe, Dekker and Nashe are looking at their single- sheet programs.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: pg. 49 NASHE "Henry V" by... No one?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: And why would any of you admit to trying to better me in a historical drama? Comedy, yes, tragedy, perhaps. But never will one of you best me in historicals. Marlowe takes a swig of ale, and spots Jonson coming to join them.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Or will we be seeing a most hysterical historical? Jonson sits next to Marlowe.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Hmm? Ben? Waiting to see how it's received before you lay claim?? Before Jonson can answer-- ON STAGE An actor, CONDELL (40's), dressed all in white (even his face is painted white) enters stage. He is "Prologue". He addresses the audience directly.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Oh, for a muse of fire, that would ascend the brightest heaven of invention. A kingdom for a stage, princes to act, and monarchs to behold the swelling scene! Then should warlike Harry, like himself, assume the port of Mars, and at his heels should famine, sword, and fire crouch for his employment. Can this cockpit hold the vasty fields of France? IN THE GALLERIES Jonson seems surprised.   This is not what he expected. This is good.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: : HORSE HOOVES as they POUND on cobblestone.   We are: 49 pg. 50 43   EXT. THE ENGLISH COUNTRY-SIDE - DAY                        43 And Southampton is riding his horse at full gallop through the countryside. About two dozen retainers follow, the first few with Southampton's coat-of-arms on flags. 44   INT. THE ROSE THEATER - DAY                                44 It is later in the play. On stage, about 15 actors are in full battle armor. They include: "HENRY V", played by the actor called Spencer, "WESTMORELAND", "EXETER", "SALISBURY". All the men on stage now wear battle armor.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: This day is called the feast of Crispian: he that outlives this day, and comes safe home, will stand a tip- toe when this day is named, and rouse him at the name of Crispian. IN THE GALLERIES Marlowe, Dekker, Nashe and Jonson all watch, obviously impressed. Nashe takes a swig of Ale. IN OXFORD'S BOX Oxford watches, loving the stagecraft involved in the production.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He that shall see this day and live t'old age, will yearly on the vigil feast his neighbors, and say 'To- morrow is Saint Crispian. ON STAGE "Henry V" speaks to his men.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Then will he strip his sleeve and show his scars. The actor playing "Henry" kneels at the front of the stage. He speaks to the groundlings as though they are his troops.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: pg. 51 "HENRY V" (CONT'D) And say 'These wounds I had on Crispin's day.' Old men forget: yet all shall be forgot, but he'll remember with advantages what feats he did that day. This story shall the good man teach his son. THE GROUNDLINGS become literally spellbound.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: And Crispin Crispian shall ne'er go by, from this day to the ending of the world, but we in it shall be remembered; we few, we happy few, we band of brothers; for he to-day that sheds his blood with me shall be my brother; be he ne'er so vile, this day shall gentle his condition: and gentlemen in England now a-bed shall think themselves accursed they were not here, and hold their man-hoods cheap whiles any speaks that fought with us upon Saint Crispin's day! The entire audience stands and CHEERS madly. OXFORD watches, with a pride he has never felt. IN THE GALLERIES The "wits" look at each other amazed. ON STAGE "SALISBURY" My sovereign lord, bestow yourself with speed. The French are bravely in their battles set and will with all expedience charge on us.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: All things are ready, if our minds be so.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Perish the man whose mind is backward now!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: pg. 52 "HENRY V" You know your places: God be with you all! THE "HUT" which is a round tower on top of the stage, contains several small cannons manned by stagehands. They shoot BLANK CANNON SHOTS. 45   EXT. THE CITY GATES OF LONDON - DAY                           45 Southampton and his retainers gallop through a City gate. Above the gate, the severed heads of murderers sit on pikes. 46   INT. THE ROSE THEATER - DAY                                   46 Actors portraying French soldiers STORM the stage, swords brandished. "Henry" and his men begin fighting them, their swordplay elaborate and impressive. 47   EXT. LONDON BRIDGE - DAY                                      47 Southampton and his entourage gallop over London Bridge. 48   INT. THE ROSE THEATER - DAY                                   48 The battle rages on stage. One hardy audience member starts to actually ATTACK one of the French "soldiers" himself. He's quickly joined by a few comrades-- and it quickly becomes a madhouse; half play, half real fight, as more audience members join the "battle". The play quickly degenerates into a bloody brawl between actors and audience. 49   EXT/INT. ROSE THEATER - DAY                                   49 Southampton arrives at the theater.   He jumps   off his horse, and hurries-- INTO THE STAIRWELL jumping two steps at a time. We HEAR the sound of APPLAUSE. The play is now over. Southampton hurries into-- 52 pg. 53 OXFORD'S BOX He sees Oxford, who is applauding.    All the actors of the play are taking their bows.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: William Cecil's convinced the Queen that only Essex can save Ireland from the Revolt. Oxford processes this.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I've pledged to go with him, Edward. We sail in an hour.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Henry--
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I ask for your blessing, Edward.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I can't give it to you. IN THE GALLERIES NASHE I for one wish to see this anonymous colleague of ours. (stands) Playwright! Playwright!! Marlowe and others join in.   And-- BACKSTAGE Shakespeare, standing next to a small table of props, quickly dips his fingers in an inkwell to make them stained. He grabs a large feathered quill and tucks a piece of parchment under his arm, then hurries-- ON STAGE --where he bows deeply, loving the adulation. IN OXFORD'S BOX SOUTHAMPTON If he is to be my king, then it is my sacred duty to be with him in battle.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: pg. 54 Oxford tries to understand Southampton, but then notices Shakespeare on stage. His mouth opens in shock, and he turns to look across the theater at-- JONSON who guiltily looks away.   Marlowe's mouth is open, his hands stop applauding. IN OXFORD'S BOX Southampton is angered by Oxford's distraction.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I am sorry to have disturbed your entertainment. And he exits.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Henry-- Henry!! But the younger man is gone. ON STAGE Shakespeare bows, then--
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: ... It's been... I, I, want to... thank my actors, whose great acting brought... my words... to life due to their most finest acting. Ah... Thank you.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: An actor?!!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: : 50   INT. OXFORD STONE - STUDY - DAY                                50 The multi-arched ceiling is painted blue with gold stars. Globes-- both terrestrial and astral-- abound. Jonson stands in front of a very angry Oxford.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: An actor for god's sake?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: My lord, I thought that--
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: pg. 55 OXFORD You presumed to think? On my behalf? Whatever made you believe you had that prerogative? A beat.   Jonson is a bit afraid.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: My lord, your voice is completely different than mine. My, my, my characters are--
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Voice? You have no voice! That's why I chose you! (beat, softer) You at least kept my name from him? Jonson NODS.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: And will continue to do so? Oxford studies him, believes him.   Then he opens a cabinet. In it, manuscript after manuscript are stacked.     Jonson looks behind him, stunned by the number. Oxford looks up and down the cabinet. He pulls one out, decides no, and puts it back, looking for just the right one... He pulls another out, then hands it to Jonson.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: A romantic tragedy. In iambic pentameter.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: All, my lord? Is that possible?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Of course it is! 51   INT. OXFORD STONE - HALLWAY - DAY                             51 Jonson exits Oxford's study, still amazed at the manuscript as he walks. He passes ANNE, Oxford's wife (now 40's), who is on her way to the study with their eldest daughter, BRIDGET (17).
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: pg. 56 She watches him go by and immediately realizes that she has seen him before. But she stays silent. 52   INT. OXFORD STONE - STUDY - DAY                             52 Oxford is writing at a desk as Anne enters.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Who was that man?    I've seen him before. Oxford holds up a finger to prevent her from speaking while he finishes writing a thought. It's a long thought. Anne is obviously annoyed, and interrupts him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Edward-- we must discuss our Bridget's dowry.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Dowry? He remembers when he spies his daughter.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She cannot go into marriage without a dowry that is becoming to the daughter of the Earl Oxford.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I can give her Brooke House and a hundred pounds.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: A hundred pounds? Father?     Mother!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: That is all we have to give at the moment. The matter over, Oxford goes back to his writing.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Edward. Edward! Speak to me! Our family is in financial ruins, and, and you, you play the flute while Rome burns! Oxford turns.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: pg. 57 OXFORD Nero fiddled whilst Rome burned. And then he goes back to writing.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: For god's sake, who cares Edward? When your own daughter can't even have a suitable dowry? She stares at him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: My god, you're writing again, aren't you? After you agreed-- after my father expressly forbade it! Oxford turns to her, full of emotion
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Anne-- If you could have seen them-- the mob... They, they didn't just sit there like the reptilia of court, faces motionless, fangs momentarily retracted. No! They, they jumped on stage, they fought the French! A butcher-- he actually broke his arm! He was so--
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Stop!   Stop it at once!! Anne storms over and grabs the parchment from under him, and begins RIPPING it up.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Why!? Why must you write?! Why must you continue to humiliate this family? He stares at her, almost uncomprehendingly.   Then--
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The voices, Anne... The voices. I, I can't stop them... They, they come when I sleep, when I wake, when I sup, when I, I, I walk down a hall! The sweet longings of a maiden, the, the surging ambitions of a courtier, the foul designs of a murderer, the wretched pleas of his victims.    Only- - only when I put their words-- their voices-- to parchment are they cast loose, freed... Only then is my mind... quieted... at peace.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: pg. 58 Anne steps back, frightened of him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I... would go mad if I didn't write down the voices. She stares at him, horrified.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Art thou possessed? He stares back at her.   A long beat
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: ... don't know.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: "Two households, both alike in dignity, In fair Verona, where we lay our scene" 53   EXT. LONDON BRIDGE - DAY                                    53 Shakespeare and Jonson are walking along London Bridge-- the only bridge that spanned the Thames at the time, it is a street lined with multi-storied buildings-- almost like a mall. Shakespeare caries and reads from a manuscript of "Romeo and Juliet"
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: "From ancient grudge break to new mutiny, Where civil blood makes civil hands unclean." (no longer reading) Incredible!! The whole bloody thing in verse?!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It's really not that difficult, if you try.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: And have you ever tried? Jonson gives him a sharp look, and pauses to pick some onions from a stand. Shakespeare notices a BUXOM BLONDE women selling apples at the next stand.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: pg. 59 SHAKESPEARE (CONT'D) (performing for the Blonde) "But soft, what light through yonder window breaks? It is the east, and Juliet is the sun. Arise, fair sun, and kill the envious moon, Who is already sick and pale with grief, That thou her maid art far more fair than she." The Buxom Blonde smiles at Shakespeare seductively.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (to Jonson) I'll have little trouble parting the legs of barmaids after that performance!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You can't play Romeo. Jonson leaves the stall, and continues down the street. Shakespeare hesitates, then gives the girl a dazzling smile. She smiles back, then Shakespeare runs after Jonson.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (to Jonson) Why not? I won't let that oaf Spencer have another go at one of my roles. No-- only Will Shakespeare can pump the life into Romeo's veins. (grins at another passing girl) And his cod piece! (beat, desperate) Ben-- Ben! I'm an actor, every inch of me, down to my very toes... I want- - no, I need, crave-- to act. I can't just idle the day by with--
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: So bloody well act like a writer! And for God's sake, keep off the stage. Writers don't have time to act.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: pg. 60 54   INT. THE ROSE THEATER - DAY                                  54 A performance of "Romeo and Juliet". About a dozen actors are dancing. It is Act 1, Scene 5. "ROMEO", played by Spencer, is staring longingly at "Juliet". "Romeo" turns to his servant.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What lady's that, which doth enrich the hand of yonder knight?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I know not, sir.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: she doth teach the torches to burn bright! It seems she hangs upon the cheek of night like a rich jewel in an Ethiop's ear; beauty too rich for use, for earth too dear! The actor playing Romeo plays to the women in the audience. And THE WOMEN respond, eye lashes twittering. THE WITS Watch in awe!   Now they're all taking swigs of ale. BACKSTAGE Shakespeare mouthing silently the lines of "Romeo". IN OXFORD'S BOX Oxford watches the dance carefully.
direction.name: direction
