direction.raw_text: Did my heart love till now? Forswear it, sight! For I ne'er saw true beauty till this night.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: pg. 61 Young Elizabeth, who is dancing with the Spanish AMBASSADOR. YOUNG ELIZABETH seems less than interested in her dancing partner.    She STARES intently back at Young Oxford. WIDER There is a natural change in the music, and all the dancers switch partners-- it's part of the dance. Young Oxford goes to Young Elizabeth, the Spanish Ambassador goes to Anne. YOUNG ELIZABETH AND YOUNG OXFORD stare into each others eyes as they dance the intricate moves.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: My lord of Oxford. Elizabeth smiles.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: We liked your play tonight very much. Your young King Henry reminded us of you.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Did he?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Rash, yet brave. A boy-- and yet a man. Fair on the eyes, fairer to the ear... WIDER Much of the Court is watching this.   They can tell there are sparks between them. All the dancers change partners, including Elizabeth and Oxford. A few dance moves, and Oxford once again finds himself with Elizabeth.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: We are glad of your return from the continent. Two years is far too long to be without such excellent amusements. Young Oxford dips his head slightly in acknowledgment.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: pg. 62 YOUNG OXFORD If I had known my absence would cause your grace so much... longing, I would have returned much-- much-- sooner. Was that a come-on?    Young Elizabeth decides to find out.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Your wife must be much pleased by your presence once more at her side... Young Oxford glances over at-- YOUNG ANNE who is now dancing with the Spanish Ambassador. But she watches Young Elizabeth and Young Oxford with a great deal of jealousy. WILLIAM CECIL Follows his daughter's look. He doesn't like what he sees any more than Young Anne does. BACK TO YOUNG ELIZABETH AND YOUNG OXFORD Still dancing.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: If she is, it is but a small comfort to me. I am returned only under my father-in-law's insistence. A beat as this sinks in.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Cecil had told me your match was one of love.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: And so he would wish. (long beat) But how could one ever love the moon, after having first seen the sun? He stares intensely into her eyes.    And she stares right back.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: pg. 63 57    EXT. RICHMOND PALACE - BALCONY - DAY                         57 Three Ladies-in-waiting run onto the balcony to join Bessie, who is looking across the palace grounds, watching-- 56    EXT. RICHMOND PALACE - FOREST - SAME TIME                    56 Young Elizabeth and Young Oxford, both on horseback, unaccompanied, trot over a small bridge. 56A   EXT. RICHMOND PALACE - BALCONY - SAME TIME                  56A The Ladies-in-waiting giggle, but are interrupted by--
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Where is her majesty? Bessie turns to William Cecil.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: My lord. Her majesty went riding with the Earl of Oxford. The Ladies-in-waiting share knowing smiles. 56B   EXT. RICHMOND PALACE - FOREST - SAME TIME                   56B Young Elizabeth and Young Oxford share flirty glances, and then Young Elizabeth spurs her horse to a gallop, and dashes into the fog. Young Oxford immediately follows.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: : 58    INT. A ROYAL TENT - LATER                                    58 A servant places a silver plate filled with shucked oysters onto a table filled with quail, venison, wine, etc... Young Elizabeth sits across from Young Oxford.   It's just the two of them dining.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: And which country did you like the most on your travels, my lord?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I think Italy, your grace.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: pg. 64 YOUNG ELIZABETH And why is that? The weather?       The food?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No their theater, which they call la Commedia dell'arte. And, of course, the women. She raises an eyebrow.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The women?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: They were more... clear with their desires than our English ladies. When they want something, they take it. They do not wait to be taken...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: 60 A door SLAMS open, and Young Elizabeth and Young Oxford dash in, ripping each others clothes off in the fireplace-lit room. Young Elizabeth gently pushes Young Oxford towards her throne... She kisses him. Then begin to make love. On the throne.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: : LATER Postcoital, the fire still lit. Young Elizabeth is half asleep, half awake, nestled in furs in front of the fireplace... much like Titania in "Midsummer Night's Dream"... Young Oxford watches her as she stirs and wakes.      She smiles at him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I can't decide. Are you Prince Hal...? Or Romeo? No. Benedick, maybe...? No-- (MORE)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: pg. 65 YOUNG ELIZABETH (CONT'D) (smiles) --Puck
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (smiles) Puck?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yes, Puck! She's only teasing.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Ah, but Puck would never fight for you in the Netherlands...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (surprised, smiles) The Netherlands? But then she realizes he's serious, and the smile vanishes.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Well, why not? It's an open secret on the continent that you support the rebels against Spain-- and that you are commissioning Englishmen to help their cause. Spain's loss is England's gain, is it not? Her eyes narrow as she studies his face.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Is this why you bedded me? For a commission?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No.   No-- of course not--    I-- She stands, wrapped in her sheets, furious at the thought of once more being used.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Leave me.    Leave at once! A beat.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Bess--
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: How dare you! How dare you!! I command you to leave my presence.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: pg. 66 And she steps back, waiting for him to exit. Young Oxford stands... and starts to approach her... He's nude, his back to us. She steps back, a bit stunned by his impertinence.   He steps towards her as--
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Mistress mine, where are you roaming? O stay and hear... your true-love's coming, That can-- (looks up and down her body) --kiss both high and low... A bit stunned by his approach, she stumbles backwards on her sheets.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Trip no further, pretty sweeting.... But he's sexy... and naked. And spouting poetry.     She stops retreating and allows his approach.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Journeys end in lovers' meeting-- Every wise man's son doth know. A small smile escapes her lips.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What is love? 'tis not hereafter; Present mirth hath present laughter; What's to come is still unsure: He starts to kiss her neck.   Cautiously at first.   But she likes it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: In delay there lies no plenty-- Then come kiss me, Sweet-and-twenty, Youth's a stuff will not endure. She responds to him, melting from both his words and touch. They start to kiss deeply, passionately... And- -
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (passionately) You will stay in England... And in... my chambers...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: pg. 67 The flash of disappointment on Young Oxford's face about that last bit is tempered by Young Elizabeth's sheet falling to the floor. They begin to make love passionately once more.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I could do it if I wanted to... 61   INT. THE MERMAID'S TAVERN - DAY                             61 Twenty-seven years later. Jonson, Marlowe, Dekker and Nashe sit silently at a table, mugs of ale in hand. Having just returned from "Romeo and Juliet", all are a bit in shock. The actors from the perfomance are there as well in the BG.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Do what?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: A play in iambic, in iambic pen...in- bic-pentameter. It's not that hard.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Think you so? Have you ever tried?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Of course not. But I could if I wanted...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It wasn't all in verse.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Ha!   See!   Even easier! Shakespeare enters and makes a bee line for them.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Henslowe wants "Romeo" to run a fortnight. (unbelievable news) A fortnight! Innkeeper! A round for everybody! Inkeeper!! (no response) Billy!!! And Shakespeare goes over to the bar.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: pg. 68 NASHE A fortnight?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The maids love the romantic tragedies.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Precisely why I avoid them.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Aw, well. No worries. A one-trick pony. He'll never be able to do it again. 62   INT./EXT. THE ROSE THEATER - DAY                            62 A MONTAGE of various plays: "TWELFTH NIGHT" Viola and Sebastian are reunited... "CAESAR" Caesar is attacked by Brutus, Cinna, Cassius, etc... "MACBETH" The witches are on stage. These three performances are INTER-CUT with: PLAYBILLS outside the Rose, announcing each play's title.      At first, Shakespeare's name is small, with each succeeding play his name gets bigger. And-- AFTER EACH PERFORMANCE Shakespeare bows to the ever-increasing applause of his audience. He looks up to see the Mermaid's Wits all watching him with stony silence. And as each play is seen, Jonson and the rest of the Wits seem more and more depressed. And after each performance, Shakespeare seems to be greeted with more and more adulation. The MONTAGE ends with...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: pg. 69 A PLAYBILL in front of the theater announcing "William Shakespeare's Hamlet". Shakespeare's name is now above the title. We HEAR the audience howl with LAUGHTER as-- 63   INT. ROSE THEATER - DAY                                     63 An actor playing "POLONIUS" does an obvious caricature of William Cecil, dressed in black with an exaggerated rendition of Cecil's beard.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: ...Beware of entrance to a quarrel, but being in, bear it that the opposed may beware of thee. Give every man thy ear, but few thy voice, take each man's censure, but reserve thy judgment.... 64   INT. WHITEHALL PALACE - AUDIENCE CHAMBER - DAY              64 Elizabeth watches the same play at a court performance. We see Elizabeth smiling amused as "Polinous" continues his rant...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: ....Costly thy habit as thy purse can buy, but not expressed in fancy, rich, nor gaudy, for the apparel oft proclaims the man. This above all, to thine own self be true. Elizabeth absent mindedly starts to scratch her chest, irritated by some sort of itch, but still focused on the play. 65   INT. ROSE THEATER - DAY                                     65 Jonson watches tight lipped... The character of GERTRUDE", the Queen, is joined by "HAMLET". "Polonius" is behind a curtain, listening in, and is seen by the audience. "Hamlet" appears enraged.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What wilt thou do? Thou wilt not murder me? Help, ho!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: pg. 70 "POLONIUS" (behind curtain) What ho, help! "Hamlet" draws his sword.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: How now?   A rat? Dead, for a ducat, dead! "Hamlet" stabs "Polonius" through the curtain.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I am slain. "Polonius" emerges from behind the curtain, covered in pig's blood, and dies an anguished death. There is stunned silence in the audience. And then one lone Groundling CLAPS, then another, then the whole audience.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Not a day too soon for old Cecil!! 66   INT. WHITEHALL PALACE - AUDIENCE CHAMBER - DAY             66 Elizabeth is still scratching her chest, but more vigorously as some of the members of court give uncomfortable glances at each other over the death of William Cecil-- er "Polonius" onstage.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: O me, what hast thou done?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Nay, I know not. Is it the King?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Thou wretched, rash, intruding fool, farewell! I took thee for thy better: take thy fortune; Thou find'st to be too busy is some danger. Leave wringing of your hands: peace! sit you down, And let me wring your heart; for so I shall, If it be made of penetrable stuff, If damned custom have not brass'd it so That it is proof and bulwark against sense.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: pg. 71 Elizabeth can't take the itching anymore. She RIPS open her bodice and violently scratches some sort of rash on her chest. 67   INT/EXT. ROSE THEATER - DAY                               67 Oxford is in his usual box, but completely alone.   He has a smile of satisfaction on his lips while... JONSON Looks over to Oxford with astonishment... While on stage the world sees for the first time "Hamlet" contemplating suicide.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: To be, or not to be: that is the question: whether `tis nobler in the mind to suffer the slings and arrows of outrageous fortune, or to take arms against a sea of troubles, and by opposing end them... Loud thunder and... RAIN STARTS TO FALL And as only the stage and the galleries are covered, the groundlings are pelted with the cold drops of water. But they stay. They stay. They cover themselves up, and silently watch on.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: ...To die, to sleep- no more- and by a sleep to say we end the heartache, and the thousand natural shocks that flesh is heir to... The audience-- soaked, pelted with rain-- watches immobile. And then a again a loud thunder clap takes us to the end of the play... SHAKESPEARE Bows to the thunderous applause. It is still raining, but nobody wants to leave. While- THE MERMAID'S WITS watch in the crowd, a complex range of emotions, but jealousy and loathing at the top of the list.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: pg. 72 ON STAGE some of the audience members grab Shakespeare, and pull him on their shoulders, carrying him triumphantly out of the theater. CUT TO: 68    EXT. STREET IN FRONT OF TOWER OF LONDON - DAY                 68 Marlowe walks towards the Tower of London. 68A   INT. TOWER OF LONDON / POLE'S ROOM - DAY                     68A Silence....Marlowe is waiting patiently... He is sitting across from Pole, the Captain of the Guard, who is reading his report....
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Are you certain of this? (almost confused) William Cecil was murdered?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Not literally, of course. He was a character, a fictional character. But the metaphor was clear for anyone to see. And see, they did. Pole reads more from the parchment.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Will you shut it down? Pole continues to read.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: That is not for me to decide... He brings out a pouch of coins, and tosses it across the table.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Your service to his lordship is once again greatly appreciated. Marlowe takes the pouch of money.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: pg. 73 ROBERT CECIL (O.S.) He butchered you! 69   INT. CECIL HOUSE - WILLIAM CECIL'S STUDY - DAY             69 Robert Cecil is furious, pacing back and forth in front of William Cecil, who sits behind a large wooden desk. William Cecil is pale and sweaty-- he is deathly ill, and sits in a wooden chair with small spoked wheels attached to the legs-- sort of an Elizabethan wheelchair.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Not only in front of Court! But the entire City as well! We must arrest this Shakespeare and-
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No, Robert, think. If he is really as popular as you say, we would only anger the mob. No. We must strike at Edward directly. William Cecil slowly-- and shakily-- bends down from his chair as--
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: But we cannot maintain our authority if the mob thinks us laughing stocks--
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Our authority comes from Elizabeth and from God! Elizabeth! Elizabeth is the key to all. Robert Cecil looks hurt by his father's anger.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Robert... You must think deeper. You must compensate. Compensate for your... malformations... with the gifts God did grant you... With cunning. With ruthlessness. William Ceci pushes a hidden button on the side of his desk-- a spring loaded secret drawer POPS open. Robert Cecil has never seen it before. Cecil produces a folded piece of parchment from the drawer, offers it to Robert Cecil.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: pg. 74 WILLIAM CECIL (CONT'D) From King James of Scotland. Robert Cecil looks surprised. 69A   INT. CECIL HOUSE - HALLWAY - MOMENTS LATER                 69A Robert Cecil is pushing William Cecil in his wheelchair. They are completely alone.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: James knows of the Queen's affection for Essex... and the rumors of his birth. He is justly concerned. (beat) You will reply to him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I will reply to him?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I am dying, Robert-- (before Robert can protest) We both know this to be true. And I will not witness the next coronation. 69B   INT. CECIL HOUSE - WILLIAM CECIL'S BEDROOM - MOMENTS       69B LATER Robert Cecil wheels his father in.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Help me to my bed, my son. (Robert Cecil does so) If we are to secure your place at the side of the next king, you must get that king his throne, not I. A beat as this registers on Robert Cecil.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You will write to James that I am gravely ill, but that all is in hand. Much of the Privy Council has already secretly agreed to his ascension to the English throne due to your tireless, but secret, entreaties on his behalf. (beat) And then tell him Essex will not return from Ireland alive.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: pg. 75 Robert Cecil looks surprised.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: This is how kings are made, Robert. So it was with Elizabeth, and so it shall ever be. There were many rival claims to her throne, but none survived to make their claim. James must know that you will do the same for him, and he will reward you for it. (beat) But we must do one thing more... William Cecil has a coughing fit-- reaches for a glass vial of medicine at his bedside-- takes it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Like Essex, Edward must be removed.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Edward? William Cecil is slowly falling asleep...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He uses the tools at his disposal, as we use the tools at ours. But ours will win... as they always have.
direction.name: direction

result.heading: OTHER SIDE OF THE SCREEN, (THEN INTERCUT EACH SIDE OF SCREEN AS NEEDED)
modifier: THEN INTERCUT EACH SIDE OF SCREEN AS NEEDED

dialogue.raw_text: : 55   INT. RICHMOND PALACE - GREAT HALL - NIGHT                    55 Twenty-eight years earlier. A dance is taking place. YOUNG OXFORD-- now 20 is dancing with Young Anne.     But his eyes are on:
dialogue.name: dialogue

result.heading: TO YOUNG ELIZABETH AND YOUNG OXFORD

dialogue.raw_text: : 59   OMIT                                                            59 60   INT. RICHMOND PALACE - RECEIVING CHAMBER - NIGHT
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: I don't understand, father.    What does Edward--
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Edward seeks what we seek.   To choose the next King. Off Robert Cecil's surprised face we hear:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I am with child...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: : 70   INT. RICHMOND PALACE - LONG GALLERY - DUSK                      70 Twenty seven years earlier. Young Elizabeth is pacing, terribly agitated. Bessie, the lady-in-waiting we have seen constantly at her side is the only other person present. 75 pg. 76 WILLIAM CECIL Are you certain? Young Elizabeth turns to Bessie.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Two cycles have passed, my lord. William Cecil thinks.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I wish to marry him... William Cecil looks startled.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Marry him, your grace? He is already married.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I can do what I will.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Can you? She gives him a sharp look.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Most of the Catholic princes of Europe wish to topple you and end your Protestant reign... The only things that stop them are the channel, and the hope that they might marry you, and thereby achieve your realm through other means. Young Elizabeth hears him, thinks on it, then begins pacing again.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I love him...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Would you risk your throne for him? Would you risk England for him? He knows the answer to that.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: We must do as we have done before... You must go on Progress, somewhere isolated, accompanied by only those whom you most trust. (MORE)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: pg. 77 WILLIAM CECIL (CONT'D) After the birth, I will find a suitable house for the child to be reared in. Young Elizabeth is uncertain.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: And Edward?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He must never know. 71   INT. CECIL HOUSE - PRIVATE CHAPEL - DAY                   71 A simple, cold space, like William Cecil himself. William Cecil is alone in prayer. A few beats, then he senses he is not alone. He turns and sees Young Oxford (still 20).
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What have you done?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I am praying.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She won't see me! I've gone to her chambers three times, and she will not receive me. And now she's gone! William Cecil regards Young Oxford for a beat, then stands.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She's on Progress. With this he leaves the chapel. 72   INT. CECIL HOUSE - HALLWAY - CONTINUOUS                   72 Young Oxford runs after him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Where?   Where did she go? William Cecil is silent.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What did you say to her? Tell me!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: pg. 78 WILLIAM CECIL The Queen does not ask for my advice about matters of the heart, Edward. If she had, she hardly would have chosen you for her pleasure. He has a point.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You must have known her eye would move elsewhere, Edward. It always has. You are neither the first, nor the last, of her lovers. Young Oxford looks up at him like a bucket of cold water has hit him. William Cecil stops. He looks at Oxford with a stern face.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Go back to my daughter, Edward. She will accept you with open arms, as she always has. Behave as your great title demands you behave. Tend to your estates, your investments. (a beat) And make me a grandson, an heir! Off Young Oxford's pained expression.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: : 73   INT. MERMAID'S TAVERN - NIGHT                                 73 Twenty-seven years later. Jonson is alone, trying to write at a small table, though it's obvious from his fits and starts and crossing outs that he is having difficulty.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It's difficult to write, isn't it? After watching something like "Hamlet"... Jonson looks up. Marlowe sits, uninvited.    Jonson looks annoyed at the interruption.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I've seen you watch him. Will. During a performance. It eats at you... at your soul...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: pg. 79 Jonson stares at him, his answer obvious.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Why do you think Will hasn't been arrested? You or I make the slightest joke about a nobleman of no consequence, and we find ourselves in a cell quicker than a fart spreads in the trade winds. Will-- he murders a caricature of old William Cecil himself, and still whores all the way to Westminster and back.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (shrugs) Perhaps they haven't noticed.. Jonson gets up and walks towards the door.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I made sure they did... Jonson turns around.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You informed on one of your own?   To the Tower?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Watch who you judge, Ben, for as God is my witness, you may well find yourself doing the same before you meet your maker. We do what we have to, to survive, and survive well, in this life. All of us. And Will is definitely not one of us. You know he's illiterate, don't you? Jonson is stunned.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No? Oh, he can read well enough-- how else could he learn his lines? But the man never actually learned to form his letters.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Why are you here, Kit?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (smiles) So who did write it? You?   No.    You'd take credit for it. No... (MORE)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: pg. 80 MARLOWE (CONT'D) It must be someone who wants their anonymity protected. Someone who might even pay to have it protected. Jonson is getting nervous.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: A nobleman. Jonson looks up.   Marlowe smiles, knowing he is closer to the truth.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: But which?    You know, don't you, Ben?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You've had too much to drink, Kit. You're beginning to sound like one of your plays. Jonson stands and hurries out of the Tavern. 73A   EXT. BANKSIDE LONDON    - MOMENTS LATER                      73A Jonson heads down the street, Marlowe chasing after him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Ben! Tell me. We can go to him together. Guarantee his anonymity... for a price.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You reported on me as well, didn't you, Kit? Last year. That's why I was arrested, wasn't it? Because you went to the Tower?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Ben, Ben... I had nothing to do with that. Jonson studies Marlowe for a beat and then walks away.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Ben-- I'll just go to Will! He'll tell me because he has so much more to lose than you. Fame. Fortune. And you'll profit nothing from it. Nothing! But Jonson is gone.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: pg. 81 74   EXT. MILITARY CAMP - IRELAND - DAY                         74 A military encampment with dozens of tents on a cliff by the Irish seaside. CLOSER Essex's tent is larger, and guarded. An OLD SERVANT carrying a tray with a silver pitcher approaches. A guard opens the tent for him to enter. INT. ESSEX'S TENT - CONTINUOUS Essex is having a Council of War with his generals and senior officers, including Southampton. They all stand around a table, consulting a map of Ireland.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: If the Rebels have stripped the northern borders... Then we must march south... and take Cahir Castle... The SERVANT stays in the background as he pours wine into various goblets. Southampton notices him-- the servant's hand shakes as he pours the wine.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: My lord. `Tis a well-defended fortress.    Two thousand men at least. We cannot-- Southampton notices the Servant's shaking hand slipping into a pocket as--
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: So what would you have me do? Spend the entire spring encamped? I am sent to Ireland to end this infernal rebellion, not idle my days with--
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Robert! In an instant Southampton draws a silver engraved pistol and SHOOTS the servant! Everyone is shocked-- but then we see:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: pg. 82 THE SERVANT had drawn his own, small wooden pistol. ESSEX shares a look with Southampton. 75   EXT. OXFORD STONE - GARDEN - DAY                           75 To Establish. A foggy day. In the Foreground we see the maze. Oxford and his fencing master, BEAULIEU (20's) are in the center of the maze dueling with rapiers for exercise. CLOSER They wear outfits that are slightly more protective than ornamental. They duel for a few moments, and then Oxford TOUCHES Beaulieu's shoulder. The speak entirely in French.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Point! Oxford backs off, as does the fencing master.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Bien. Faisons du travail... le Coup droit d'autorite?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Mais oui, mon seigneur.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Bien.    En garde! And they once again begin to duel. But we quickly surmise something is amiss. Beaulieu is much more aggressive than he was before. Oxford realizes it, but is an expert swordsman, and defends himself well. And then Beaulieu aggressively moves forward, and STABS Oxford in the leg.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Qu'est ce que vous faites? But Oxford has little chance to react, because Beaulieu continues his attack.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: pg. 83 OXFORD (CONT'D) Beaulieu?    Beaulieu?! This has become an assassination attempt, not an exercise. ENTRANCE OF THE MAZE Francesco is entering the maze with a silver tray carrying a pitcher and two goblets. CENTER OF THE MAZE Though wounded, Oxford is a superior swordsman. And he begins his own attack-- with a ferocity that surprises Beaulieu. IN THE MAZE Francesco heads for the center as-- IN THE CENTER OF THE MAZE Oxford PIERCES Beaulieu's heart with his rapier, and Beaulieu SCREAMS-- IN THE MAZE Francesco hears the scream, and starts to run.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Signor?    Signor?! IN THE CENTER OF THE MAZE Oxford collapses as Francesco rushes in.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Signor? Mio dio! Signor! What has happened-- Oxford checks his leg wound, and glances at the dead Beaulieu. He tries to wave off Franceso's aid, but to no avail as--
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Beaulieu-- he, he tried to kill me... 76   EXT. BANKSIDE LONDON - DAY                                  76 Jonson, slightly drunk, walks down a street, a whore under his arm, and notices a commotion up ahead: people talking by an alley near the Mermaid's tavern.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: pg. 84 JONSON (to a passer-by) What's all that, then?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: A body... Jonson peers over and sees: A BODY on its back in the alley. Someone turns it over.    It's MARLOWE, a dried stab-wound in his eye. JONSON is stunned.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Must have been a cut-purse. Nowhere's bloody safe anymore, I'll tell you that...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: : 77   INT. A BEAR-BAITING THEATER - DAY                            77 A small, open air theater where a chained bear is being led around the theater. A set of mastiffs are being led on the opposite side of the theater. The spectators are unruly, loudly making bets for the mauling to come. Jonson is among them, taking a look at the bear, deciding whether to bet on it or not.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Sampson! Sired by the great Arthur himself! No dog's yet been bred that can take him down! Shakespeare suddenly sits next Jonson hardly notices.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I need more money.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: More--? You already make more than any playwright Bankside.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: pg. 85 BEAR BAITER But then here, good friends, I bring you a pack of dogs so fierce, so dangerous, that Medusa herself would shrink in fear!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'm going to build my own theater, Ben, one that fits the scale of my work-- Jonson suddenly turns to him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Your work?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Not a one has had a morsel of food in a week! Bred by the great John Sinclow!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Fourpence on three dogs!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: They insist only a gentleman can own the land.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: A shilling on four!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The bribes are outrageous, but I found some one who will make me a coat-of-arms, and change the Stratford lists for me.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Impossible.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Eight shillings on six dogs!   Eight shillings on six dogs!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'll take that bet!!   Eight shillings on the bear, six dogs!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Done!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Bad bet, that.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (to Shakespeare) You'll have to make do with what you've got. I won't be your beggar.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: pg. 86 Shakespeare gives him a look to kill.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: This isn't a request, Ben.   I'll have more money.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Or what? You'll slit my throat like you did Kit's?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Release the dogs!   Release the dogs! Shakespeare shows no reaction.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I know he went to see you last night, Will. And I know he was planning to expose you if you didn't agree to his terms. IN THE PIT The bear baiting begins. WIDER Shakespeare stares at Jonson.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You're mad, Ben. Kit was my friend.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Be careful, Will. You kill me off too, and you won't have any good plays to act in after this is all done. Some of the spectators BOO while others CHEER, and--
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'll have my guineas, Ben. One way or another, I'll have my guineas. And he gets up and leaves as the-- DOGS start to go for the bear's throat.     Thge cheering goes to a roar as we--
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: : 86 pg. 87 SHAKESPEARE Wears a beard and fake nose. He tries to stay hidden so Jonson doesn't see him. We are: 78    EXT. LONDON BRIDGE - DAY                                      78 Jonson is waiting not far from him by a stand and drinks an ale. Then Oxford's servant, Francesco, appears. After the two men have exchanged couple of words, Francesco gives Jonson a leather folder containing a manuscript and a purse jingling with coin. Jonson takes them and leaves. Jonson safely gone, Shakespeare starts to follow Francesco who heads back over the bridge. 78A   EXT. THE THAMES RIVER - DUSK                                 78A Shakespeare is in a small boat following Francesco, who is in Oxford's boat. They head towards Oxford Stone. EXT. OXFORD STONE - DUSK Shakespeare watches as Francesco enters Oxford Stone. 79    OMIT                                                          79 CUT TO: 80    INT. OXFORD STONE - STUDY - DUSK                              80 Shakespeare is waiting, clearly uncomfortable. It's not the kind of room he's used to being in. He holds his wig and his nose. A door opens, and Oxford enters, walking on a stick because of his leg injury. He is followed by his servant, Francesco.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: So! You are the famous Shakespeare whose labors I have enjoyed so much. I am at your service, sir.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: pg. 88 Shakespeare is uncomfortable. He wasn't expecting Oxford himself. Then he just goes for it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: My lord-- I- I need more money.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (sharp) I beg your pardon?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: My expenses have, ah, aggrandized... since this all began.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: "Aggrandized"?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: And if, if your lordship doesn't agree to an increase in my, ah, fee, I shall be forced to make certain... facts public.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Have you any idea to whom you are speaking?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I am addressing the writer of Hamlet... of Juliet and her Romeo.   Am I not? Oxford is silent. Francesco goes to physically eject Shakespeare from the room.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Out. Get out! How dare you insult my master in--
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Wait! (beat) How much? Shakespeare looks at Francesco, then Oxford.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Four hundred pounds. A year.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: A year?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Pay him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: pg. 89 Francesco is shocked.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Pagalo! Shakespeare smiles. 81   EXT. OXFORD STONE - DUSK                                   81 Shakespeare exits, tossing a leather pouch filled with coins. He smiles. 82   INT. OXFORD STONE - STUDY - DUSK                           82 Oxford watches Shakespeare walk down the road through a window.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Forgive me for speaking of things above my place or understanding, signor. But... Is this wise? They have already tried to kill you once.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Wisdom, Francesco, is a quality I have unfortunately never possessed... Francesco stares at Oxford who is deep in thought. The sound of heated love making takes us to... 83   INT. CECIL HOUSE - YOUNG OXFORD'S BEDROOM - NIGHT          83 Twenty-five years earlier. Young Oxford (now 25 and with a beard) is making love to someone. We can't tell who at first, and assume it is Elizabeth. And then we see, it's BESSIE, Young Elizabeth's lady-in-waiting.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: 84 An hour later, post-coital. A fire is burning, and Bessie is finishing dressing herself.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Edward... You know she would be furious if she found out about this...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: pg. 90 Young Oxford doesn't answer. He is deep in thought.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She still loves you.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No.   She abandoned me.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You don't know, do you? He looks at her quizzically.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The Queen.   She had your child. 85    EXT. CECIL HOUSE - EARLY MORNING                           85 A carriage drives towards the house. 85A   INT. CARRIAGE - EARLY MORNING                             85A Young Anne de Vere holds her sleeping daughter in her arms. 86    INT. CECIL HOUSE - HALLWAY - EARLY MORNING                 86 Bessie carefully closes Oxford's bedroom door and suddenly freezes. She turns and sees Young Oxford's wife with her little daughter at her side standing in the hallway staring at her. For a moment nobody dares to move, then Bessie rushes off...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I cannot be certain, majesty, when the... relationship began.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: : 87    INT. RICHMOND PALACE - GREAT HALL - DAY                    87 Young Elizabeth looks out a window, obviously distressed. William Cecil is across from her, his face tense. 90 pg. 91 WILLIAM CECIL But sometime soon after your return to Court.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You're sure?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: They-- they haven't been very discreet, majesty. I presume he wanted you to know. To... to hurt you. She is crushed.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Majesty, there is more. The lady is pregnant. Young Elizabeth freezes, stunned.   Then--
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Arrest them.    Arrest them both! William Cecil bows and exits. Now alone, Young Elizabeth lets her emotions out.   She picks up a vase and THROWS it into a wall. 87A   EXT. TOWER OF LONDON - DAY                                87A From high above, we see a carriage arrive.    It stops, and William Cecil gets out. 88    INT. TOWER OF LONDON - YOUNG OXFORD'S CELL - DAY           88 Young Oxford (now 26) is looking out a window at the river beyond. He has been imprisoned for some months. His beard has become ragged, his clothes have seen better days. William Cecil enters.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Your whore gave birth last week. Young Oxford turns to William Cecil. The stare at each other for a beat.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: pg. 92 WILLIAM CECIL (CONT'D) The Queen has decided to release you. It seems time does indeed heal all wounds. (beat) These are her conditions for your release. One. You will not acknowledge the child. Two. You will never see the mother again. Three. You will avoid Court at all costs. Her majesty would prefer not to be reminded of you in any way ever again. A beat as Young Oxford thinks on all this.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Banished...?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No. You have the freedom of the kingdom. Just not of the Court. (beat) Those are her terms. Here are mine. You will go back to my daughter. You will make some effort to make her happy and you will finally act according to your station in life, and accept the responsibilities of your great title. Oxford reluctantly NODS.    William Cecil goes to leave.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: My lord!     I, too, have a condition. William Cecil turns.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I will go back to your daughter if... You tell me the name of the child.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I don't know if the whore has even delivered the--
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No.   The other one. Cecil's face goes to stone.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The other one? (realizing) Who told you?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: pg. 93 Cecil is obviously annoyed by this development.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I will go back to your daughter. I will make you as many grandchildren as she can bare... William Cecil thinks.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Or I can remain here... William Cecil decides.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: There is no record of his true birth, no trail that leads to you, or the... mother. His foster parents never knew the truth, and both are now dead...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The name?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Make even a hint of this to the child, or anyone else, and this agreement is void, and I'll see your head on the block within a fortnight. And the boy's as well.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It's a boy...? 89   EXT. CECIL HOUSE - GARDEN - DAY                             89 Young Oxford (cleaned up) is watching a BOY about five years old dueling with a tutor. The boy is quite good. The boy notices Young Oxford, and stops duelling.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Hello...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Hello. Young Oxford smiles at the boy.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'm Edward, the Earl of Oxford.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: pg. 94 BOY My lord... The Boy bows, a serious expression on his face.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: They tell me one day you're to be an Earl as well.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I shall be the Earl of Southampton.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Well then, we shall be Earls together, shan't we?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: : 90   INT. WESTMINSTER ABBEY - DAY                                    90 Twenty-five years later. William Cecil's body is in state, in his coffin, in the center of the apse. ELIZABETH looking completely stricken, approaches the coffin, holding Cecil's white cane. She places it at his side. In the background we hear the Archbishop of Canterbury reading from the bible.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: ... In the sweat of thy face shalt thou eat bread, till thou return to the earth: for out of it wast thou taken, because thou art dust, and to dust shalt thou return... ROBERT CECIL scans the room, to see how it is all playing out. OXFORD watches stoically, his wife and children at his side.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: pg. 95 91   EXT. WESTMINSTER ABBEY - DAY                                91 The funeral over, Elizabeth exits the portal of Westminster Abbey and heads to her carriage. A huge crowd of mourners has assembled. Robert Cecil steps into place right behind her.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: We wish to recall Essex from Ireland... Robert Cecil is instantly concerned, but hides it well. They continue to walk.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: We feel a terrible void, now that your father is no longer at our side... Robert Cecil bows his head as he walks.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: A wise decision, your majesty. If nothing else, it will give him an opportunity to respond to all these rumors. Still walking, she turns to him sharply.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Rumors?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'm sorry, majesty, I thought you'd heard.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Heard what?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Essex is in negotiations with Philip of Spain...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Peace is at hand. We know this.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Majesty-- it is said that Essex has promised Phillip all of Catholic Ireland in return for... He hesitates.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: pg. 96 ELIZABETH In return for what?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Spain's support of Essex's claim to the throne of England... They have arrived at her carriage.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It is, as of yet, just rumor.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Bring him to me, William.   Bring him to me at once!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Robert, majesty. Elizabeth stares at him for an instant, then gets into her carriage, unsure of herself.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: My father's death has been a great loss for us all... She ignores him, trying to collect herself. Robert Cecil turns to the driver, NODS, and the carriage takes off. As soon as it is away, Robert Cecil turns and some in the crowd of commoners begin to BOO at him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: : HORSE HOOVES as they gallop over emerald green grasses.   We are: 92   EXT. A MILITARY FIELD IN IRELAND - DAY                        92 A group of horsemen gallop into Essex's camp. A MESSENGER jumps off his horse and heads for Essex's tent. 93   INT. ESSEX'S TENT - DAY                                       93 Where Essex and Southampton are having dinner as the messenger enters. He bows. 96 pg. 97 MESSENGER My lord... He hands him a sealed envelope. Essex takes it, begins to read. Frowns, SLAMS the parchment down. He looks into the distance, trying to process what he's just read. Southampton picks up the parchment and begins reading.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She can't believe this...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Oh, can't she?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It's Robert Cecil. He failed to kill you, now he tries to kill your name. Essex heads for the flap of the tent.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: We leave with the tide!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: : 94   INT. THE MERMAID'S TAVERN - NIGHT                             94 Shakespeare enters the tavern carrying a rolled up parchment. He passes various actors drinking, then hurries over to Jonson, Nashe and Dekker, who are deep in drink.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Well, I've got it! Shakespeare unravels the parchment.   He puts it on the table with a flourish. It shows a coat-of-arms containing a spear and a falcon. The colors are numerous, and garish.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The herald just finished it not an hour ago. (smiles) Well? Everyone is confused by it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It's quite... colorful.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: pg. 98 DEKKER What in blazes is it?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: My coat-of-arms! It cost a bloody fortune, but, by god, you can call me gentleman now! Jonson looks over at Shakespeare. Shakespeare locks eyes with him, but looks away, ashamed of something.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I can't quite make out the motto... Non sanz... Non...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: "Non sanz droict".
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Not without--
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Right!? Not without right? (beat) You went to him, didn't you? You lying knave-- you went to him! Shakespeare doesn't want to discuss this with the others present.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (smiles) Ben.   Ben! Let me buy you a-- He grabs Jonson's shoulder, but Jonson pushes him away.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What? You've already killed off one competitor. Now you want another dead as well? Shakespeare looks at the confused Nashe and Dekker nervously.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I don't know what you mean.   Ben, we should really--
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I swore to him I wouldn't tell you his name. Swore it! Do you have any idea what he might do to me? Do you? (to Nashe) (MORE)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: pg. 99 JONSON (CONT'D) He's not even a writer you know. He can't even--
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Ben-- you've had too much to drink. Shakespeare grabs Jonson.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Unhand me! Shakespeare backs off. Jonson pulls out a piece of parchment from his shirt.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Here! (looks around) A quill! A quill! Nashe and Dekker look at each other, slightly embarrassed. Jonson finds a quill deep in his pants. He thrusts it at Will, who ignores it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Go on, Will. Write something for us. Now. Go on! Amaze us with your verse. Your wit! No? Try astounding us with the letter "E". Or an "I"-- it's just a straight line! Shakespeare stares at him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You haven't got any ink. And he exits.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: : 95   EXT. THE CITY GATES OF LONDON - DAY                         95 Southampton and Essex are on horseback, followed by several dozen armed retainers, GALLOPING towards the city of London. 96   EXT. WHITEHALL PALACE - COURTYARD - DAY                     96 The party rides into the first gate. The palace is the city residence of the Queen, and is at the edge of the City. 99 pg. 100 Essex and Southampton jump off their horses. 97   INT. WHITEHALL PALACE - HALLWAY - DAY                        97 Essex and Southampton walk quickly down the long hallway, opening door after door. Servants scurry behind them, terrified of the intrusion, trying to stop them. They open the doors into-- 98   INT. WHITEHALL PALACE - AUDIENCE CHAMBER - DAY               98 The ladies-in-waiting scream in fear when they see the two men in battle gear.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Wait for me. And he continues on into-- 99   INT. WHITEHALL PALACE - OLD ELIZABETH'S BEDROOM -            99 CONTINUOUS --where Elizabeth is still dressing, putting on make- up, etc. She is NOT wearing her wig, and is only wearing her undergarments. She looks quite ugly. She turns to see Essex, shocked at his intrusion. Essex FREEZES.   He knows he has just made an enormous faux-pas.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Majesty, I, I... She stares at him, horrified to be seen in such a manner. The she regains her composure and--
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Get out!   Out!!! He steps back in horror-- not at her appearance, but what he has just done. The doors SLAM in front of him as we--
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The insolence!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: pg. 101 100   INT. WHITEHALL PALACE - AUDIENCE CHAMBER - DAY              100 Elizabeth, now dressed and wearing her wig on her throne, is raging at Robert Cecil.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Who in God's name does he think he is? Abandoning his post without my leave! She begins to absent-mindedly unbutton the top of her bodice.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Coming into our presence in such a manner, neither announced nor invited, half his army in my courtyard. He's gone mad... mad!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No. Unfortunately for us, your majesty, he is quite sane. He simply believes he is your royal equal. She turns to him sharply, furious at the thought. 101   EXT. ESSEX HOUSE - DAY                                      101 It looks like an armed camp, with part of Essex's army encamped in the front courtyard. The soldiers are all tense. Oxford, followed only by Francesco, rides into the courtyard. He is immediately surrounded by armed men, their muskets pointed at him. Oxford raises his hands.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I am Edward, Earl of Oxford.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Edward!   Edward! Thank god you're here. Southampton comes towards him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Elizabeth has revoked all of his royal licenses! She believes every lie Cecil tells about him. (seeing Oxford's wound) Edward? What happened to your leg?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: pg. 102 OXFORD (shrugs) Nothing. Oxford continues towards the door. Southampton follows, his concern for Oxford's wound noticeable. 102   INT. ESSEX HOUSE - HALL - DAY                                102 Oxford, Southampton and Essex are alone. Oxford is sitting in a chair, while Essex paces impatiently, Southampton standing between them.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She won't accept my letters. I cannot get to her. Cecil plans to arrest me any day. I know it. (beat and more determined) But that won't be as easy as he thinks.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Fight him in London, and you only validate every rumor and lie Cecil has ever told about you.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Then what do you suggest I do? Let myself be arrested so I can be tried and executed for crimes I did not commit?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No. I will go to Elizabeth, myself, alone--
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: How? Cecil won't let her see a letter without reading it first.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I won't send her a letter.   I will send her a book. Essex looks confused, but Oxford ignores it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She will call for me. And while I am with her, you will come-- not with an army, not with swords, but with her loyal subjects. The cobblers, the tinkers, the bricklayers of London. (MORE)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: pg. 103 OXFORD (CONT'D) All, all calling for Robert Cecil's banishment from Court. Words, Robert, words, will prevail with her, not swords. Essex looks unsure.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: And the mob?    How will I-- OXFORD Leave that to me. 103    OMIT                                                         103 103A   INT. OXFORD STONE - A STUDY - NIGHT                         103A Oxford is in his rooms, writing feverishly by candlelight. He completes a thought... closes the manuscript... writes down the title with a flourish: The Tragedie of Richard III 104    INT. A ROOM ABOVE THE MERMAID'S TAVERN - DAY                 104 A room for the whores to take their tricks.    Small, with nothing much beyond a straw bed. Shakespeare is bedding a buxom young lady. And then the door OPENS. Francesco enters, and Oxford follows, holding a manuscript. Shakespeare looks shocked. She starts to SCREAM and yell as she pulls a sheet to cover herself.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Hold your tongue, whore, and get out! She does so as Oxford walks over to Shakespeare. He tosses the manuscript to him. Shakespeare starts to look at it. The whore is partially dressed, so--
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Out, woman!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Oi.   `Oo's going to pay me then?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: pg. 104 Shakespeare gives a look to Oxford-- he certainly isn't going to pay for it. Oxford nods to Francesco, who gives the whore a few coins. She smiles, and leaves.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You shall begin rehearsals immediately. But it is not to be performed until I tell you. And you may only have a day's notice. Shakespeare looks confused.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: That will be expensive-- keeping all the actors ready. Having the props made but not-- Oxford tosses a very large pouch of coins at him, and then begins to leave.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Oh, and congratulations. You've had an epic poem published today.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Published? You mean like in a book? Renaissance MUSIC BEGINS as we--
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: : A PIECE OF PAPER as a printer presses down the press onto it. The title page is printed in front of us. It's called "Venus and Adonis". A MONTAGE BEGINS. 105   INT. A PRINT SHOP - DAY                                      105 And the printer brings the page out from the press and checks it for proper alignment.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: `The boar!' quoth she; whereat a sudden pale, Like lawn being spread upon the blushing rose... Usurps her cheek; she trembles at his tale, (MORE)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: pg. 105 SHAKESPEARE (V.O.) And on his neck her yoking arms she throws: The printer nods his approval...   The poem continues with: 105A   EXT. THE PRINT SHOP - DAY                                  105A Shakespeare exits the Print Shop, continuing to read the book, now out-loud.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She sinketh down, still hanging by his neck, He on her belly falls, she on her back. (not quoting) Oh, I like this...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: : 106    OMIT                                                        106 A COVER OF "VENUS AND ADONIS" that is held by a woman.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: 'Fondling,' she saith, I'll be a park, and thou shalt be my deer; Feed where thou wilt, on mountain or in dale: We are: 107    INT. WHITEHALL PALACE - AUDIENCE CHAMBER - DAY              107 A LADY-IN-WAITING is reading out loud to other Ladies. They listen giggling now and then. We only see them from the back.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Graze on my lips; and if those hills be dry, Stray lower, where the pleasant fountains lie.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: pg. 106 SECOND LADY IN WAITING (continuing) Seeds spring from seeds, and beauty breedeth beauty; Thou wast begot; to beget is thy duty. By law of nature thou art bound to breed... They look up and see-- ELIZABETH standing across the room.   How much has she heard? WIDER They all stand abruptly, worried. The women who was reading the book puts it down on a table. Elizabeth silently walks over to them, and picks up the book. She opens it as we-- CUT TO: 108   INT. WHITEHALL PALACE - HALLWAY - DUSK                         108 Robert Cecil walks down the long hall, heading for an audience with the queen. Two guards open a door, letting him into-- 109   INT. WHITEHALL PALACE - OLD ELIZABETH'S BEDROOM - DUSK         109 Elizabeth is looking out the window. It's raining outside. She is NOT wearing her wig, not much make-up, and looks quite... odd. Robert Cecil enters.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You find me disgusting, don't you? Repugnant. Wrinkled?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You, you are the sun, majesty.   The glory of--
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Liar! Robert Cecil shuts his mouth.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: pg. 107 ELIZABETH (CONT'D) Is it so hard to believe that once I was young? That I was... beautiful? Your father knew me as such... (beat) You have read the book? She doesn't have to say which one. Robert Cecil sees a copy of "Venus and Adonis" on a table. He NODS.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He writes to me. To remind me of that beauty. That love. How I... took him. How I... adored him... Robert Cecil knows to be silent.   She looks out the window.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (throaty, sexually) Graze on my lips; and if those hills be dry, Stray lower, where the pleasant fountains lie... She smiles seductively, transported in time.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I've been foolish. Proud. Yes. Too proud. Gloriana... The Virgin Queen... A statue. Bloodless. (beat) "Thou wast begot; to beget is thy duty. By law of nature thou art bound to breed, That thine may live when thou thyself art dead"... (beat) Your father told you of the child? A beat.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (hint of a smile) Which one, your majesty? Elizabeth's eyes flare in anger for an instant, then she regains composure.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: His.   Mine.   He still lives? Robert Cecil nods.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: pg. 108 ELIZABETH (CONT'D) He was well placed? A nobleman?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (hesitates) Yes... your majesty.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Who? Robert Cecil hesitates.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I am your Queen! Now who is my son!!?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: His grace, the Earl of... Southampton, your majesty. She seems surprised. Perhaps she was expecting Essex. But then she smiles, and NODS in approval.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Majesty... You are not having doubts about James of Scotland succeeding you, are you? Elizabeth goes into a rage.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: James?! He is the son of Mary! She plotted and schemed to steal the throne from under me! No son of hers will rule while a yet Tudor lives! Robert Cecil is surprised by her fury. He bows his head as Elizabeth tries to collect herself.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I will decide what is best for my kingdom! Not you! Not you!! (calmer) I have bid Edward to come to me on my return to London on Monday next. It is decided. She says no more, the audience over. Robert Cecil hesitates, and then she glares at him... He bows and exits, the fury on his face plain. Elizabeth looks at her own reflection in the window...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: pg. 109 ELIZABETH (CONT'D) (sotto) And so, in spite of death, I shall survive, In that, my likeness still is left alive. CUT TO: 110    EXT. BANKSIDE LONDON - DAY                                   110 Ben Jonson walks with a manuscript in his hands. He stops for a moment when he sees the new Globe theater. Workers are still painting the walls. He pauses when he sees a poster in front advertising a performance of "Richard III" on Monday next. 110A   INT. THE GLOBE THEATER - DAY                              110A Jonson sticks his head in and takes in the glorious new theater Shakespeare and Burbage have built. The actor Condell is on stage, rehearsing the character of "Gloucester". He walks on stage with a limp, and has a large hump on his back. He is a caricature of Robert Cecil.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: But I, that am not shaped for sportive tricks, nor made to court an amorous looking-glass... Richard BURBAGE, the theater's stage manager, is watching his performance with Spencer and a group of actors. Jonson stops and watches the rehearsal for a beat.
direction.name: direction

result.heading: IN THE CENTER OF THE MAZE

dialogue.raw_text: : 84   INT. CECIL HOUSE - YOUNG OXFORD'S BEDROOM - NIGHT
dialogue.name: dialogue

result.heading: A ROOM ABOVE THE MERMAID'S TAVERN

direction.raw_text: that am curtail'd of this fair proportion, deformed, unfinish'd, sent before my time into this breathing world...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Good part, that...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: pg. 110 "GLOUCESTER" ...and that so lamely and unfashionable that dogs bark at me as I halt by them. (out of character) Is this wise?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It's only the one performance.   Go on!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I need a drink... And "Gloucester" heads backstage.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (to Burbage) Burbage. Wonderful theater. Wonderful! The best Bankside! But only one performance? Is it that bad?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Hardly, it's Will's new play. Richard the Third. We've been hired to perform it free to the public.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Free?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Aye. Some anonymous nobleman paid for everything. God knows Will never would.   Been rehearsing all week, just found out this morning, we go up next Monday. Jonson thinks a beat-- that's odd-- but then holds up his manuscript.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (grins) My best so far. I guarantee more than one performance. Though I'll not pay for the tickets myself. (winks) No need to.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Sorry, Ben... Jonson looks confused.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: pg. 111 BURBAGE (CONT'D) Will... He's part owner... I'm sorry Ben, but I had to agree no Jonson plays at the Globe... Ever. Jonson is in shock. CUT TO: 111   INT. THE MERMAID'S TAVERN - NIGHT                              111 Jonson is deep in drink, by himself.   He listens as patrons of the bar say:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You doin' tomorrow?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You askin?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Managed to get two tickets to Shakespeare's latest. Cost me a fortune.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Ballocks, did it! They're giving them away free. Some of the actors from the rehearsal enter, all jolly and excited. They head for the bar. They are: The ACTOR WHO PLAYED "GLOUCESTER", Spencer, Pope, Heminge, etc...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Best villain in the history of theater, Richard the Third. No doubt.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Come on.    Better than Mephistopheles?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No doubt! Your Marlowe-- god rest his soul-- is fine for your everyday scalawag, and your Jonson won't even try the hard drama. No, this is Shakespeare, for god's sake! The man knows drama. I tell you, not even the Greeks compare! (toasting) To Shakespeare! And villainy!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: pg. 112 ALL To Shakespeare! And villainy! Jonson gets up, furious, and exits, quite drunk.     The actors don't even notice him. 112   EXT. STREET IN FRONT OF TOWER OF LONDON    - NIGHT           112 Jonson stumbles down the streets, alone, deep in his own private hell. It's raining.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Fancy a tumble? Only sixpence! Jonson waves her off.     He looks up and sees: FROM HIS POV: The Tower of London. He makes a decision. 113   OMITTED                                                      113 114   INT. THE TOWER OF LONDON - POLE'S ROOM - DAY                 114 Jonson sits in the same spot where Marlowe was sitting earlier. And he hates himself for it. Rain drips down the windows. Pole looks up from some papers.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I haven't got all day, man.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: ... There is a-- there is a play to be performed... on Monday.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: There's many plays to be performed next Monday, isn't there?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yes, my lord, but this one is to be performed one performance, and one performance only. On Monday. All Bankside is talking of it. (beat) The History of King Richard the Third. By William Shakespeare. Pole is confused.   So?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: pg. 113 JONSON (CONT'D) He kills his brother the king, and half the royal family to get the throne for himself--
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I know who Richard the Third was.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yes. Of course you do. But in William Shakespeare's version, he is played as a hunch-back. Pole realizes this is significant. 115   INT. CECIL HOUSE - THE PRIVATE CHAPEL - DAWN                115 Robert Cecil has prayed all night. His lips silently move in a prayer for a miracle. When Pole appears he doesn't stop his prayer. Only after Pole whispers in his ear does he stop and look slowly up to the simple cross and close his eyes in relief. 116   EXT. LONDON - DAY                                           116 From high, high above a city of 200,000 souls. It's a beautiful sunny day, but black storm clouds are on the horizon. All of London is on its feet. They all are on their way to Bankside. The London Bridge is crammed one way. The River Thames is full of many small boats of theatergoers. 117   EXT. BANKSIDE - IN FRONT OF THE GLOBE - DAY                 117 We see that a huge crowd has formed in front of the Globe. 118   INT. THE GLOBE THEATER - BACKSTAGE - DAY                    118 Everyone is busy, preparing for the performance; actors, stage-hands, etc... Shakespeare adjusts an actor's costume when Burbage walks up besides him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: pg. 114 BURBAGE We have to turn `em away by the hundreds! Look! Never seen anything quite like it! And both men look out the curtains to the crowd outside. The theater is full to the last seat. The people are crammed together like sardines. 118A    INT. OXFORD STONE - OXFORD'S ROOM - NIGHT                   118A Oxford is being dressed in front of a mirror...    His finest clothes... Powder to face... Francesco assists him. 118AA   INT. THE GLOBE THEATER - THE GALLERIES - DAY             118AA Jonson is leaning against the edge of the balustrade, watching the Groundlings fill in. He bites his nails nervous. Nashe joins him as--
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: So! I heard the Earl of Essex paid for this whole performance! Man's never even been to the theater, and still he's heard of Will-- Dekker also joins them.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Essex!? Impossible. My cousin's one of his men-at-arms. Hasn't been paid in weeks. They're all just sitting there, waiting.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Waiting?     Waiting for what?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Wants to have an audience with the Queen. As if Cecil would ever let Essex near her now.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: By the mass, Cecil in favor, Essex out! Who can keep up with it all!? (takes a swig) (MORE)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: pg. 115 NASHE (CONT'D) Zounds, I tire of politics, politics, politics. 119   EXT. THE THAMES RIVER - DAY                                   119 Oxford is in a long-boat, headed for Whitehall Palace. The oars of the boat cut neatly and silently into the water. 120   INT. WHITEHALL PALACE - OLD ELIZABETH'S BEDROOM - DAY         120 Elizabeth is doing her toilette. She seems excited like a school girl before her first date. Her Ladies in waiting are attending to her. 121   INT. THE GLOBE THEATER - DAY                                  121 The audience HUSHES as-- ON STAGE "GLOUCESTER", the future Richard III, enters. He is hunch-backed, and looks as much like Robert Cecil as possible in terms of beard and costume. First the people are in stunned silence, but then like magic the hissing starts. It is followed by more hissing and the first boos. The actor playing Gloucester nervously looks around... IN THE GALLERIES Dekker seems surprised at the similarity to Robert Cecil.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Tired of politics are you? Seems you picked the wrong day to come to the theater, then... Jonson gives Dekker a sharp look.   What's going on here? ON STAGE "Gloucester" addresses the audience.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Now is the winter of our discontent made glorious summer by this son of York. Grim-visaged war hath smooth'd his wrinkled front....
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: pg. 116 The hissing and booing has swelled so strong that the actor stops for a moment. But then he finds the courage again to continue. Jonson looks down at the Groundling's reaction, and spots-- FRANCESCO in the audience. But among the Groundlings, not in Oxford's usual box seat. JONSON looks over to Oxford's box.   It's empty.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: ...and now instead of mounting barded steeds to fright the souls of fearful adversaries, he capers nimbly in a lady's chamber to the lascivious pleasing of a lute. But I, that am not shaped for sportive tricks, nor made to court an amorous looking- glass... 122   OMIT                                                           122 123   INT. WHITEHALL PALACE - ROBERT CECIL'S ROOM - DAY              123 Robert Cecil watches himself in a mirror as armor is placed on him by servants.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: that am curtail'd of this fair proportion, deformed, unfinish'd, sent before my time into this breathing world,.... 124   EXT. BANKSIDE - IN FRONT OF THE GLOBE THEATER - DAY            124 The huge crowd has stayed in front of the Globe. It seems they are waiting for something. We hear hissing and booing from the crowd inside the theater.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: ...and that so lamely and unfashionable that dogs bark at me as I halt by them.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: pg. 117 125   INT. THE GLOBE THEATER - DAY                                  125 On stage, "Gloucester: continues despite the concert of hissing and booing...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: And therefore, since I cannot prove a lover, I am determined to prove a villain and hate the idle pleasures of these days... 126   EXT. ESSEX HOUSE - DAY                                        126 Essex mounts his horse, Southampton at his side. Their sixty or so men behind them ready for the march to Elizabeth.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Edward knows what he is doing...      Does he not?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He promised us a mob. They'll be here. Essex looks concerned, but says no more. 127   INT. WHITEHALL PALACE - ROBERT CECIL'S ROOM - DAY             127 The servant tightens the last strap of Robert Cecil's armor. He smiles at himself in the mirror.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Plots have I laid! CANNONS DRAWN BY HORSES as they roll down a cobbled street.   We are: 128   EXT. LONDON BRIDGE   - DAY                                    128 Soldiers move people and carts off the street. Others put CANNONS into place and then cover them with canvas tarps.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Inductions dangerous, by drunken prophecies, libels and dreams, to set my brother Clarence and the king in deadly hate the one against the other.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: pg. 118 129   INT. THE GLOBE THEATER - DAY                                  129 Shakespeare watches from backstage, getting more and more nervous by the audience's reaction.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: A pox on you!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: A pox on Cecil!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: A pox on Cecil! A pox on Cecil! The actors are getting nervous.      People start throwing lettuce and tomatoes at them.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Why is Oxford's man with the Groundlings? BACKSTAGE Shakespeare and Burbage exchange a worried glance. 130   EXT. ESSEX HOUSE - DAY                                        130 The BELLS of St. James' Cathedral mark the hour as five o'clock. Essex looks to Southampton nervously. 131   INT. THE GLOBE THEATER - DAY                                  131 The play continues. "Gloucester" is plotting yet another death on his way to the throne.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Hath she forgot already that brave prince, Edward, her lord, whom I, some three months since, Stabb'd in my angry mood at Tewksbury? A sweeter and a lovelier gentleman- Fram'd in the prodigality of nature,     Young, valiant, wise, and no doubt right royal- FRANCESCO Down with Cecil! The actor playing "Gloucester" hesitates.     The audience is getting unruly.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: pg. 119 FRANCESCO (CONT'D) Up with Essex! To Essex House!     To Essex House!! IN THE GALLERIES Jonson is putting the pieces together.   He stands.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: This is what Essex is waiting for-- (realizing) Oxford is bringing him a mob. Jonson heads for the stairs.
